text: 'Garbage in, garbage out Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems like a good idea for the environment and economy. But it might not be. In many developed countries, people have their rubbish collected regularly. They put their rubbish bags or bins outside, and a special truck takes them away. Usually, this service is free because it is paid for by local taxes. This means a family that throws away a lot of rubbish pays the same as a couple that throws away very little. However, getting rid of rubbish is not free. The more rubbish there is, the more collectors and trucks are needed, and the more local authorities have to pay for landfill. This is a basic economic problem: if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. The simple solution is to make people pay for the rubbish they throw away. This would encourage them to throw out less and recycle more, if there are places to recycle. But two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, found that this idea can have unexpected and sometimes disappointing results. They studied several American towns and cities that started charging for rubbish. The most common system is to sell stickers or tags for rubbish bags or cans. Only bags with these labels are collected. In a study, they looked at a scheme in Charlottesville, Virginia, where people paid 80 cents for each tagged bag. The number of bags fell by 37%, but this was because people packed more rubbish into each bag. The weight of rubbish collected fell by only 14%. In other Virginian cities without this scheme, the weight fell by 3.5% anyway. Some people also dumped rubbish illegally to avoid paying. This is hard to measure, but it might account for 30-40% of the reduction in collected rubbish. On the positive side, recycling increased by 15%, but this might not be because of the fee, as many people were already recycling. In another study, Fullerton and Kinnaman found that charging for rubbish does reduce the weight of rubbish, but not by much. A 10% increase in sticker prices only reduces rubbish by 0.3%. To reduce rubbish a lot, people would need to buy less of everything. A small fee is unlikely to change much. Other factors, like income and education, might be just as important as price. In richer towns, people throw away more rubbish and have less time to recycle. So, should we stop charging for rubbish? Not really. Free disposal is too cheap. But simple policies can have complex effects, and sometimes the results are not what we expect.'

**Work and Change**
Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life might change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Just having a successful career is not enough anymore. Many people feel their jobs are not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy. Loving your job used to be special, but now you need to think about how your job affects you as a person, your mind, character, and relationships. This is important. No matter how good you are at your job, if it makes you boring or unable to talk to others outside your field, or if you are too busy to learn new things or be creative, then no amount of money or status will make up for it.
I am exploring how work can help us grow as people, instead of just shaping us to fit industrial needs. Work should not only be about making money but also about living a fulfilling life, discovering new talents, and meeting different people. This change does not mean ending unemployment. As people become more educated, they want jobs that are interesting and meaningful. A career should be like a work of art, with a happy person at its center.
Even traditional jobs like doctors, accountants, and architects are not as appealing as they used to be. Doctors are often more stressed than their patients. Accountants worry about their profession's ethics. Architects rarely get to be creative. Administrators are stuck in bureaucracy. Middle managers are losing confidence in their roles. Companies and public institutions are getting smaller. Ideas like decentralizing decisions and rewarding performance have not made employees more committed. In Britain, only 8% of employees strongly feel their values match their organization's values.
I am studying different jobs to see how they shape or sometimes harm people. I have looked at how different cultures expand what humans can do and how courage can be developed. I have focused on happiness, love, friendship, and respect. Now, I am looking for more satisfying ways to work. Many experts focus on making companies last longer and earn more money, but we also need to think about what kind of people we want to be and who we want to spend our lives with. How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many of us are like part-time slaves, stuck in jobs because we see no other choice?
Take hotel workers, for example. Ten percent of people work in the hospitality industry. Many smart and lively people work long hours for low pay and little respect. Hotels have not changed much since the days of the Ritz. They are not just places to sleep but could be cultural centers where people from around the world meet. Hotel staff, often foreigners eager to learn, have only brief interactions with guests. Hotels could connect guests with the city and each other. They could use the skills of the students they hire, instead of giving them only simple tasks. If hotels focused on their staff's true ambitions, they could offer many more services. But accountants often say hotels should focus on one main activity to make the most money.
It's time to rethink what work means, from a human perspective, not just a financial one. Work is a relationship. People want jobs that allow them to be independent and express themselves. They should have the chance to design their own jobs and choose their colleagues and customers, within practical and profitable limits. This means they need to communicate beyond professional language and connect with different minds. Everyone knows communication is important, but true conversation is different. It is a deeper connection that creates respect and can change you. It is more than just relaxing; it is a way to create equality. Every meaningful conversation changes the world a little bit.

**Broadcasting: The Social Shaping of a Technology**
The word 'broadcasting' originally meant spreading seeds by hand over a large area. This is not just an agricultural term; it also represents the idea of planned growth and success. Broadcasting involves spreading information from a central source, much like planting seeds from a central bucket.
When new technology allowed words and pictures to be sent electronically, it was organized in a way that fit this agricultural metaphor. Television, like the telegraph and telephone, is a form of communication. However, from the start, it was seen as a central 'mass' medium, sending information from one place to many homes. This matched the social and economic structures of modern societies.
There were some experiments with different ways of organizing television. For example, in the 1930s, radio amateurs in Britain tried two-way television, similar to a telephone. Magazines like Radio News showed how to build TV transmitters and receivers. But in 1938, big companies set standards that pushed these small experiments aside.
In the early 1930s, television was mostly watched in public places, not just in the USA but also in Britain and Germany. Public viewing was common, and some thought it might challenge the idea of TV as a home-based medium. However, as technology improved and prices dropped, TV sets became more common in homes.
As people in Western countries gained better living standards from the 1920s, the idea of the home as a center for entertainment became possible. This trend is now happening worldwide. Broadcasting became a way for governments to efficiently reach all citizens and create a sense of national community.
Broadcasting also played a role in democracy, providing equal access to information for informed participation in society. However, as technology changes, the term 'broadcasting' might become outdated, referring only to a specific period of centralized media.

**Clutter**
Sometimes it feels like no matter how many things you own, you never feel safe. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes the desire to get more things goes too far. Modern advertising is made to make us feel insecure. It often tells us that if we don't have certain things, we are not good enough. To see how much you are influenced, try not to read any advertising signs next time you walk down the street. These expensive messages try to convince us to buy things in very clever ways, often without us noticing. We see them everywhere - on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, the internet - all telling us to buy, buy, buy.
**Caves**
Research centers and universities around the world have spent many years studying caves, especially their origins, water systems, and life forms. Caves are a small but mysterious part of nature, which makes us curious and eager to learn more about them. Because they are natural wonders, caves have been studied for a long time, especially in places where they have affected how people live. However, visiting many caves requires physical skill, so cave research is often done by both scientists and people who explore caves for fun.
**Weather Watch**
Many observant people, using only their senses, started the study of weather, which has become a very technical science since the 17th century. Satellites and electronic tools now give us a lot of weather information quickly, and computers solve complex math problems faster than humans can. Weather science uses many long words that are hard for non-experts to understand. It might seem like there is no room for simple weather knowledge, but that's not true. Human experience is still important for turning computer data into weather forecasts. Human observations can still give unusual information that helps professionals understand the atmosphere better.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**
Until recently, I thought opera was mainly theatre. Now, I see that opera is mostly about music. I learned this while working at a national opera house. In theatre, the words and the actors are most important. There is no one directing the action once the play starts, and the audience usually speaks the same language as the performers.
At a music performance, like in a concert hall or opera house, many people, like me, might not understand music technically. Some might feel embarrassed about this, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. A great singer or a perfect orchestra is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows years of hard work. Watching top-class music is like watching a sports match. We know athletes do something similar to us running for a bus, but they do it much better.
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They might not understand an actor's skill and might not be impressed by something that seems easy to do. They often ask actors, "How do you learn all those lines?" This doesn't mean theatre audiences are less demanding than music audiences. Many people go to both. But in theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms, no matter how difficult the play is.
Does music need to learn from theatre about this relationship? I think yes. Music performances are full of emotion and can be very theatrical. But the way music is presented, with strict dress codes and respect for conductors and soloists, can feel too formal. Sometimes, audiences clap at the wrong time, which can interrupt the performance.
Many people are working to make music more accessible and to break down barriers. I remember a special event, Jonathan Dove's community opera "In Search of Angels," which moved from a cathedral to the town. It was a high-quality musical experience and life-changing for many in the audience, who also participated.
I wish music had more of the risk and excitement that theatre can have. Sometimes, using unusual locations can surprise both performers and audiences. It might be uncomfortable, but theatre audiences are used to following artists into unexpected places. Most plays are performed in a traditional way, like in a concert hall. But I believe music conventions can change. I love both theatre and music and want more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**
I admire how sand can be turned into useful things like glass and concrete. However, I don't like sand in its natural form. For me, it is a difficult barrier between a car park by the sea and the water. Sand blows in your face, gets in your food, and hides important things like car keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you like glue and is hard to remove, even with a strong water spray. But, strangely, when you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, sand falls off you. For days, you find sand on the floor every time you take off your shoes, and more sand appears when you remove your socks. Sand stays with you longer than some illnesses. I prefer to avoid sand.
**Lock and Key**
People have always wanted a safe home for privacy and security. In the past, a wooden beam might have blocked the door, but now we have electronic locks that use plastic cards. These cards can have more combinations than there are atoms in the universe. However, people still want to keep out the 'bad guys'. The idea of a lock and key is partly psychological. Some companies have tried using computerized locks with smart cards that control electronic locks. But people don't like them much. At work, it might be okay, but at home, everyone wants the comfort of turning a real key in a lock. So, when a locksmith company made a new electronic system, they included a real metal key in it.
**Modern Art**
I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because, like many people, I don't understand modern art. I know I like some of it, especially furry things, neon light sculptures, and big photos. Maybe if I knew more about it, I would have more opinions. But you are not supposed to analyze art like a school essay. The idea is to let art communicate with you. This is a great idea, but it never worked for me. However, this new gallery tries to help visitors understand the art. The first thing I noticed were the labels. These labels explain the art and tell you what it is trying to say. Instead of just staring at the pictures, these bits of information helped me understand.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**
Adapting novels into films often means reducing, condensing, and deleting parts of the story. This can be frustrating for writers, but it can also be enlightening. When I worked on a script, I noticed that I could remove a lot of dialogue and description from a scene in the novel and still convey the same message. This doesn't mean the original dialogue and description were unnecessary. It's about the kind of attention each medium requires from the audience and the type of repetition each uses. In a novel, repetition might include mentioning character traits multiple times or using speech tags like "he said." These help readers understand the story better. In stage drama, which is mostly speech, real conversation is imitated with some style. In some modern plays, this is extreme, making the dialogue seem full of unnecessary language, only serving to connect speakers without clear communication.
**Watching Movies**
Watching movies can make you feel like you're part of the film's world. It's an experience that takes you away from reality for the film's duration. Once the movie ends and the lights come on, you're back in the real world. People often don't feel responsible for the time spent watching a film, and this feeling of unreality can make it hard to take movies seriously as an art form. In the past, some people, including our parents' generation and teachers, saw movies as just entertainment, not art. They enjoyed being entertained but didn't consider movies to be an art form.
**The Film Studios**
The Leiper Film Company studios were a mix of many different buildings. The layout was confusing and hard to understand. There were a few permanent landmarks like the Script Department, but most rooms looked the same and were used for meetings. Finding a specific room was difficult without help. The studio didn't have a clear main entrance, which added to the confusion. There were three main entrances, all similar, and only one led to where you wanted to go. There was no place to ask for directions. Strangers rarely visited because the studio didn't encourage it. Employees, however, knew their way around and worked together to create movies that brought romance and adventure to audiences. For a few hours, characters like Jane and George, Sally and Dick, would escape from everyday problems, thanks to the studio's efforts.
**Film-makers**
Many people want to make movies. Bookshops have many 'how-to' books on scriptwriting and film production. Universities offer courses, and there are competitions for aspiring filmmakers. Robert Rodriguez made the film El Mariachi with a low budget of $7,000, which made him famous among American independent directors. In his book about making Mariachi, he recalls his 23rd birthday, thinking about how Orson Welles made Citizen Kane at 25 and Spielberg made Jaws at 26. He felt he had only a few years to make his breakthrough film. In the past, filmmakers took time to mature. They worked behind the scenes as editors, writers, or cinematographers and directed low-budget films to learn the craft. John Huston was 35 when he made his first film, The Maltese Falcon. Fred Zinnemann, director of High Noon, found success in his forties. Today, without studio or TV support, aspiring filmmakers often have to be independent.

In those days, the council houses covered the western side of the city. They were rows of small, dull houses made of orange half-brick or pale white stucco. In summer, chemicals from the May and Baker factory, two miles away, would fill the air with a strong smell of sulphur. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose as he walked up to someone's door. I have forgotten most of my early life, but I remember sitting near an upstairs window, looking at the houses as they disappeared into the distance. Later, I have other memories - faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that I don't think was ours, and snow falling over the big mansion at Earlham.
My mother often appears in these early memories. I remember her as a small, precise, and often angry woman. I never understood why she was angry, so I couldn't do anything to make her happy. Even as a child, when I went with her to the small shops in Bunnett Square or on longer trips into the city, I knew she was different. She was the most solitary person I have ever known, as alone in a room full of people as on a moor. She also had a strict sense of proper behavior, which was unusual in West Earlham. This sometimes led to furious cleaning or handwashing and telling me to 'behave properly'. I didn't understand this as a child, and even now, I'm not sure I do. It meant not walking into neighbors' gardens or damaging their rose bushes, sitting quietly in the dining room with hands folded, listening to radio programs my mother liked, and many other rules.
Despite her solitude, my mother had some friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who rarely spoke, and Mrs. Laband, who was livelier and not fully approved by the others. Later, I realized they were not great company. They often talked about bad legs, cold weather, and ungrateful children, a group I felt I was part of. Looking back, it felt like a heavy weight of the West Earlham houses, my mother and her friends, and the need to 'behave properly' was on my shoulders, and I needed to grow up to lift it. This was not easy. Growing up in West Earlham followed a set pattern. Until you were five, you stayed at home. I remember boring days when I was about four, playing on a rug while my mother sat in an armchair. After your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school, half a mile towards the city. Some lucky children had a mother with a bike and a child seat. I think my mother let other children take me to school.
If I remember anything about these early years, it's the summer holidays. These were days when you saw glimpses of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next to Mrs. Buddery who told stories about his time in the Merchant Navy. Once, there was a charity event at a house far away, where a kind woman gave out lemonade and tried to interest me in something called the League of Pity, a junior charity. But my mother dismissed it, saying they were 'only after your money'. My mother often talked about people wanting money, and she had a low opinion of politicians. She thought of the House of Commons as a place where rich people took money from the public. I might be exaggerating, but my mother didn't have much kindness. However, she did care about my education. Sometimes on Sundays, she would take me on the 85 bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. We would walk through rooms of paintings by the Norwich School of Artists. My mother didn't mind this activity and even started to have opinions on the paintings. I remember her once joking about a painting of a Roman soldier, saying, 'Well, I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!' This was a rare moment of humor from her.

**Philadelphia Avenue**
I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the side with odd numbers. The evening was getting darker, and the air was thick with a light, prickly rain. This made my walk feel secretive and special. I knew this side of the street very well; it was where our neighbors, the Matzes and the Pritchards, lived, along with Han Kieffer's grocery store, and the homes of my first friends, all girls. Even though I didn't know everyone by name, each house was unique to me, just like the small channels in the sidewalk that carried rainwater to the street. As the street went downhill, the houses seemed to get smaller, and the front yards became tiny. Over the years, things had changed: wooden porch railings and pillars were replaced with wrought iron, in a style that seemed Southern or Spanish. In Shillington, some houses I remembered as homes had become stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, had become homes again. I wondered how people lived in those spaces that used to be shops.
**Bachelor Fads**
Rick Gilbert, a furniture designer, lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has typical loft features like exposed brickwork and big doors. But Gilbert didn't want an open-plan space because it was hard to separate work from home life. So, he used a large sheet of corrugated plastic to divide the space. This created a hallway and led the eye to the kitchen in the middle of the flat. He wanted the kitchen to be a neutral area for both cooking for friends and making coffee for clients. To balance the modern look of the plastic and steel, he used light wood for the floors and filled the flat with sentimental furniture from his parents or markets.
**Bruce Chatwin**
Bruce Chatwin's life was full of secrets and stories. He was a brilliant writer, and his first book, "In Patagonia," published in 1977, changed travel writing. It was exciting like a thriller and imaginative like romantic fiction. Chatwin often mixed fact with fiction to make his stories more interesting. He believed that through travel, one could discover histories that seemed to exist just to fascinate future explorers.
**Swimming**
One summer, during a heavy rain, I swam in the pool behind my house. The rain made bubbles on the water, and when the storm got stronger, it felt like the pool was rising to meet the sky. It was then, in the summer of 1996, that I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea and escape the routine of swimming back and forth in a pool. Many places today are labeled and explained, but activities like walking, cycling, and swimming let us explore the wild and mysterious parts of the world. A swimming journey would let me experience the mystery of nature, like dark woods or high mountains.

'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that humans cry for no clear reason. He was probably wrong. More recently, scientists have said that crying is important for social reasons. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps create a bond between mother and child. Many people think that tears, especially in children, show helplessness. But why adults cry is harder to understand. It seems that the sound of crying is less important than what it shows visually. Crying might have helped early human groups by building trust and social connections. Tears can also happen for other reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for people facing injustice. Also, we might cry without wanting to, which can be embarrassing, when we hear beautiful music or moving speeches. We might cry during a sad movie, but this happens more often when we are with others than when we are alone. The social role of crying seems clear, but research is still ongoing.'

**The Heat is On**
We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it change our lives? Many people have an idea of what global warming is, but not everyone knows its effects. A warmer climate will likely change the weather everywhere. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on Earth, changes in climate will affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans use these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. Any changes to these resources are important.
The problem is understanding how the world will change and what causes these changes. In the last 100 years, human actions have increased the amount of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are linked to global temperature. These gases are likely affecting the climate, but we don't fully understand how the global heat balance works, making the future uncertain. We do know that greenhouse gases and global temperatures have changed together over the past 40,000 years, suggesting they are related. Evidence shows that Earth's surface has warmed by about 0.6°C over the past century. Most scientists believe this warming is partly due to human pollution.
A lot of research uses computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs) to predict climate conditions. These programs use physics and chemistry to study temperature, pressure, solar radiation, and other factors. However, they are not perfect and can be slow and costly. We don't fully understand all climate processes, but we know the climate system is complex. Despite these challenges, most people agree that climate change is happening faster than before. GCMs help us understand what the world might be like in the future.
Currently, predictions suggest that by 2100, the average global temperature will rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, sea levels will rise by 15-95 cm, and rainfall patterns will change. Extreme weather, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts, may become more common. These changes could impact the environment and humans. Climate change can affect where ecosystems like forests and grasslands are located, the species they contain, and their ability to provide benefits to society. This includes food production, water resources, and human settlements. Some effects may be irreversible and harmful, but not all. Some impacts might be beneficial. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have increased wheat yields since 1952.
However, many predicted effects of climate warming are not beneficial. Small climate changes can affect water availability, especially in dry regions or areas with existing shortages. The Mediterranean Basin is one example, where rainfall patterns have changed. Another effect is changes to glaciers, which will impact ice, vegetation, wildlife, and human structures. The Arctic ice might melt completely, making transport and exploration easier but increasing iceberg risks.
The most visible effect of global warming could be rising sea levels. This happens because warmer water takes up more space and melting ice adds to the ocean. With half of the world's population living in coastal areas, rising sea levels could cause severe problems. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo might face flooding. Many people could lose their homes, creating environmental refugees. Small island nations could be most affected, as they might disappear if sea levels rise too much. This would be devastating for their people and culture, and other countries would need to help those displaced.

'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong both physically and emotionally. This will be the profile of the first astronauts to go to Mars if multi-millionaire Dennis Tito's plans to launch a capsule on 5 January 2018 are successful. The capsule will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. The spacecraft will use Mars's gravity to return to Earth without using more fuel, as saving fuel is very important. The 2018 date is set because the next time Mars and Earth are in the right position for a launch is in 2031. It is a big challenge, and new technologies need to be developed quickly. If everything is ready in time, the spacecraft might succeed. But even if it doesn't launch, the work done will help future missions.'

'AESTHETICS Sometimes, the existence of art can make it hard to understand aesthetic theory. This is because art is often seen as just physical objects like buildings, books, paintings, or statues, separate from human experience. However, the real art is what these objects do in our experiences. This misunderstanding can make it difficult to truly understand art. Also, when art becomes famous and admired for a long time, it can create fixed ideas that block new insights. Once art is considered classic, it often gets separated from the human experiences and conditions that created it. This separation makes it hard to see the true meaning of art, which is what aesthetic theory tries to explain. Art is often put in a special category, away from other human activities and achievements. 
The main job for someone writing about the philosophy of art is to connect art with everyday life experiences. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of human experience. To understand art, we need to look at ordinary experiences, not just the art itself. For example, to understand how plants flower, we need to know about soil, air, water, and sunlight. Similarly, to understand art, we need to start with everyday events and scenes that catch our attention and give us enjoyment. 
Many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, and comic strips without thinking of them as art. This is because art is often seen as something only found in museums and galleries. But the desire for enjoyable experiences finds its way into everyday life. People who disagree with the idea of art being only in museums still often separate art from everyday life. The best times for appreciating art are when it is closely connected to everyday activities.'

**Observing Lions**
People often think of lions hunting as a perfect team. In the evening light, a group of quiet lions jumps from the shadows and surrounds their prey. Lions seem like social animals that work together for a common goal, like getting their next meal. However, after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have a different view. We started our research in 1978, hoping to learn why lions hunt together, raise cubs, and scare off rivals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many surviving offspring it has, then working together might not always be best. If an animal is too generous, others benefit at its cost. So, why don't lions follow the usual rules of self-interest? We thought we could answer this in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. Like the noble gases krypton, argon, and neon, we would add lions to the list of things that don't react much. It has taken many research methods to find clues about lion behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now getting answers to our questions.
**Pop Music Review**
The release of Bedrock's third album was a big moment for the band. "New Life" started a movement that changed rock music in this country for the rest of the decade. The old style of serious music with loud guitars was replaced by a lighter, more melodic style. The album mixed social observations with humor and irony. Bedrock showed they were good at collecting different styles and writing songs. They sang about traditional English topics like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. But the album's real strength was in its deeper, more emotional songs like "So Low" and "To the Brink." "New Life" is a beautiful album with 16 high-quality tracks and no filler, which is rare in the era of long CDs.
**Extract from an Autobiography**
As a child, I was fascinated by stories of "The Sibyl," wise women from the ancient world. I first heard about them in a story my mother told me. An old woman offered nine books to the King of Rome for 300 gold pieces. He refused, and she burned three books, offering the remaining six for the same price. When he refused again, she burned three more books. He finally bought the last three for the full price. I learned a lesson about salesmanship and life from this story. As a lonely child, I often asked to play with others and was refused. My mother told me to do something interesting so others would want to join me. It worked, and I never forgot that lesson. When I was asked to write a travel book, I looked for something I was interested in. I'm not a big traveler, so I sent my editor a list of places I didn't want to go. I'm only interested in ruins because I like to travel through time in my mind.
**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**
When you submit your manuscript, it usually goes into a pile waiting to be sorted. This pile is called the slush pile. The person sorting it is often a junior editor or an experienced freelancer. They don't have much influence, but they want to find something original. The junior editor wants to make a name for themselves, and the freelancer wants to keep their job. If they like your novel, they will pass it to a senior editor. At an acquisition meeting, the editor must justify accepting your novel based on its quality and potential sales. They also consider if you, as an author, seem like a long-term prospect. They will have to say how promotable you are, which is important for a new novel. Publishers often like to meet a potential author before making an offer.

**Advertising Challenges in the Early 1990s**
If you worked in an advertising agency in the early 1990s, you probably faced a very difficult time. The recession was severe, affecting many countries for the first time in thirty years. In Britain, 1991 was especially tough. The economy shrank, interest rates were high, people spent less, many lost their jobs, and thousands of homes were repossessed. Every business felt the impact, with some industries like vehicle and building trades seeing a 30% drop.
Advertising professionals were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They were expected to help improve company profits while working with smaller budgets. They were told to achieve more with less money. Despite these challenges, the importance of marketing grew. Companies started focusing more on creating products and services that customers wanted, rather than just what was easy to produce. This shift increased the status of marketing professionals but also added to their responsibilities.
Marketing was seen as a solution to many problems, and since about half of marketing budgets were spent on advertising, the pressure was on advertising professionals. The 1980s were a great time for advertising, but the 1990s started with a downturn. This was partly due to the economy, but also because companies began questioning the value of advertising. They wanted to know exactly what they were getting for their money.
Client companies demanded better strategies, creativity, and media placement from advertising agencies. They wanted the best people working hard to produce excellent work. Advertising professionals faced the same challenge as their clients: doing more with less. The recession made it hard to take risks, which are often needed for good advertising.
Other challenges included demographic changes, the growing power of retailers, changing consumer needs, more legal restrictions, and the challenge of advertising in foreign markets. These factors forced advertisers to rethink their strategies. They needed to figure out which parts of their advertising were effective.
Finding help to improve advertising was not easy. Companies and agencies were busy dealing with these challenges and were not eager to share their successful strategies. Conferences and seminars offered some help, but books on advertising often did not provide practical advice. They sometimes gave the false impression that all advertising work was of high quality and good value for money, which was not always true.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**
When I was at university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice among my friends. Cooking was not a popular job that many of us wanted. Being a chef seems difficult: the work is long, stressful, and not well-paid. But these things didn't stop me. I was unhappy at university. The studies were hard, and the social life was closed and self-important. Being a chef seemed like the perfect way to escape from that. It offered a seriousness and honesty that I didn't find in my college life. But my wish to cook was not just because I was a student. It also showed an artistic dream. I first saw this dream when I ate a meal at a famous London restaurant. It was amazing. I still remember my starter. After that meal, I wanted to thank the chef who made it. I felt happy for days. After this, I wanted to learn the secrets of this wonderful art. I changed my student life to prepare for my future in cooking. My history degree felt empty, taking me away from my real goal. I learned about cooking by reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making fancy meals.
**The Swimming Instructor**
The school's swimming teacher was a former drill sergeant, small and strong, with tattooed arms. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced that move until the hour was over. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. The instructor was strict, and every time I came up from the water, he looked at me with disapproval: 'Don't look down, look up!' 'Keep your legs straight.' 'Point your toes, I said!' The next week, I went up onto the high board. It was a fixed board, and its front edge bent slightly downward. It seemed very high as I stood there, trying to be brave. Slowly, the echoing voices disappeared, and I felt like I was in silence. I moved my arms as I was taught, tried to look up, not down, and jumped into the air. For a brief moment, I was flying. When I hit the water, I fell awkwardly, and my legs were everywhere. The instructor looked at me with contempt and shook his head. But even he could not take away my happiness. That's what they mean by 'free as a bird', I thought.
**The Traveller**
For those of us who value a comfortable bed, running water, and the chance to live at least until tomorrow, the idea of the traveller is both confusing and interesting. These are people who choose to risk their lives by climbing dangerous mountains, sailing alone in small boats through big seas, eating insects if there is nothing else, and living for months in the unknown. It is easy to see these people as strange - and they are - like hermits, freefall divers, or writers. They exist, but their unusual world is far from our daily life and can be ignored, we think, as unimportant. We can go back to our world of microwave ovens and phones, happy that the only risks we face are predictable ones, like crossing a busy street.
**Sailing**
Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, saying it is not his natural place, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He does not say he is a top sailor, though he is clearly a good one. His main reason for sailing is that, as a writer, he likes to write about sailing. Sailing gives him exciting stories to write about. Raban's small boat has an electronic device that tells sailors their exact position anywhere on earth. He likes this tool, but he also has a simple view of other sailing aids. He thinks the compass was a bad invention, causing a 'big change in the relationship between man and sea'. Raban believes that since it was invented, about a thousand years ago, it has become the main focus for sailors, so they no longer study the waves and feel the sea. The ocean, once full of life, is now just a space. Since the sailor's job is just to stay on course, he can be replaced by an autopilot for long times. This may be why Raban had time to look so carefully at the waves.

**Holiday Reading**
Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are connected. Books help us feel more at home in the world. We can relate to experiences in books, even if they were written long ago or far away. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can describe situations we thought were unique to us. They express our thoughts clearly, which we might struggle to do. This is even more amazing if the book was written in a different place or time. We feel thankful to these authors for helping us understand ourselves. Through reading and travel, we break free from routine. Our eyes are most open when we are in a new place or reading a great book. Books help us notice things we ignored before. We become aware of the sky's colors, a friend's behavior, or a hidden sadness we didn't know we had.
**Author's Note**
These travel reflections were published in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have made some small changes, but added very little. I corrected a few mistakes, but only if they were important. For example, in an article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell a year later. If I changed the article to predict this, it wouldn't be a true report from that time. Like any traveler, I was there at that moment, not knowing what would happen next. This is the story of mass travel: the world opening up to people who can afford a ticket. I believe that travelers are not blind. Even a postcard can have a purpose.
**Ecotourism**
If there were awards for overused tourism phrases, "ecotourism" would win. The term started in the early 1980s, when people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators realized travelers wanted to believe their trips wouldn't harm the environment. "Ecotourism" became a popular marketing term. Now, it includes anything from living with remote tribes to a short boat trip. Any tour with cultural interaction, nature, wildlife, or adventure is called ecotourism. The original idea was to help people make informed choices, but without clear rules, travelers are confused about what ecotourism really means.
**Transylvanian Journey**
I lost my notebook from my Transylvanian journey for 50 years, but found it again by luck. It helped me remember that time, but not completely. In Transylvania, I had an easier time than expected, staying in friendly country houses for weeks. When I stopped traveling, I stopped writing, thinking there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again, and sometimes only made short notes. I worried that some details might be out of order, but then decided it didn't matter. This book is not a guidebook, so I let the story tell itself.

**Fashion**
Fashion is often thought of as a modern idea, linked to the growth of capitalism in the 1800s and 1900s. However, many fashion historians say that fashion, in terms of style and design, has a long history. They often start with the market and trade growth in the 1500s and 1600s. As societies have become more complex, populations have grown, and new ways to make different clothes and accessories have been found, the meanings of clothing have also become more complex. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing or accessory means. For example, a man's suit, which seems very uniform, can have different meanings in different situations and to different people.
**Writer**
News stories about publishers fighting over new manuscripts have given a false idea of what life is like for most novelists. For those of us not on the best-seller lists, there are two ways to make a living. The smartest among us write in the evenings and have other full-time jobs that are secure even if the book doesn't sell well or become a movie. Others, like me, do various small jobs, such as teaching, running workshops, and writing articles like this one. I've heard of a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I've never gotten anything like that. Somehow, by juggling part-time jobs and credit cards, and often with help from the people thanked in the Acknowledgements, the novel gets written.
**Sudden Fame**
The small places we were performing at around the country were starting to sell out, and extra security was needed to manage the growing number of screaming girls. We had to use secret entrances to the venues to avoid being surrounded by fans. On the few nights we weren't working, it was hard to leave the house without being chased by followers. In just a few days, we became celebrities. Our fans watched our every move, and our management and others took care of all our needs. Even though I was always shy, it was replaced by a strange confidence that only naturally shy people in similar situations can understand. In short, I was emotionally overwhelmed.

**Music - The Future Challenges**
Technology is changing our lives at work, home, and in our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, we had more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. But, live music performances and full-time jobs for musicians have decreased. More people can now access music, which meets many human needs. Music is important for national events and personal activities. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn musical instruments.
I believe people will still want to learn instruments. The music industry is a big part of Britain's economy, and musical skills are important for many jobs, especially in media. Playing an instrument can also help develop skills early in life. Research in the USA shows that music can improve spatial reasoning, a part of intelligence. Although these results need more proof, studies in Europe show that group music lessons can improve social skills and concentration in children.
Research is also looking at how playing an instrument can help develop other skills. For example, regular practice can help with good study habits, and playing in concerts can teach punctuality and organization. Because of these benefits, there will likely be a demand for music lessons in the short term.
In the long term, music might change in two ways. First, people will listen to more diverse music, with new genres mixing different styles. Second, technology will be used more in composing and performing music, making it easier for people to create music without needing technical skills. This might reduce the need for live performances. More people of all ages might want to make music in their communities, reflecting their local traditions.
To prepare for this future, music teaching needs to change. More people should be able to learn different instruments throughout their lives. The way we teach and assess music will need to adapt to include a wider range of skills. Musicians will need to inspire and teach people of all ages, work with large groups, and have skills in communication, social interaction, and management. This is a big change from traditional methods and will require accountability. This change is an opportunity to show the quality of music education.
Finally, we need to raise the importance of music in our lives. Music is crucial but often taken for granted. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**
Sometimes, people make fun of actors. This often happens because actors talk about their work in interviews. They should respond like the dancer Pavlova, who said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it." Instead, actors often use boring phrases or get caught up in gossip. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, once wrote to a friend that an actor's work is only interesting when performed. Talking about it makes it seem empty. Acting has no strict rules, except maybe being heard clearly. With each new play, actors start fresh, learning and growing with the characters and the writer's ideas. When a play ends, the actor feels empty until the next one. This emptiness is clear when discussing theatre work.
**A Review of Hamlet**
Adrian Lester's performance as Hamlet is a mix of youth and maturity. His acting is simple yet confident. He handles the text well and shows great control, making him a standout actor. Lester plays a young man full of hidden anger, using humor and wit to be both strong and likable. His performance is skillful, even if it seems understated. Watch how Lester's body moves, like he's waiting to come alive. Handy, who plays Horatio, gives a similar impression. This raises questions: What is acting? What is behavior? Is acting just copying real life, or is it something more? These are key questions in theatre.
**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**
This director starts rehearsals with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen. Actors sit quietly, listening to others speak and feeling the words' impact. When it's their turn, they look at the screen, think about the words, and find a reason to speak. For example, if the line is "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" they breathe, imagine the scene, and find the impulse to speak. This director believes in discovering what's happening without planning too much. Actors should trust that something will happen if they keep an open mind.
**The Perfect Theatre**
The perfect theatre makes you feel like your presence matters. Going to a live performance is special, and the staff should feel this too. It's not good if the staff treats it like just another job. The theatre should connect the performer and the audience. Everyone should see and hear clearly and feel involved. The size of the theatre is important; it should fit the human voice and body. Many theatres from the late 1800s got this right, creating spaces that embrace the stage. I like theatres with a sense of history, like worn steps in a church. You can't please everyone with a play. Audiences don't always know what they want to see. When you go to the theatre, you want to see something surprising, something you couldn't imagine at home.

**Paul Simon and Rock and Roll**
In the 1950s, rock and roll was mainly popular with young people. However, it also had a big impact on middle-class and older people. It helped create the next group of rock stars, who listened to it and felt it would be important in their lives. For Paul Simon and other young people in the US, the best way to hear this exciting new music was on Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. Freed's show was a must-listen for many future rock stars. Like young John Lennon in Liverpool, who listened to Radio Luxembourg to hear rock and roll, Paul Simon was amazed by the music on Freed's show. He was ready to move from just listening to music to making his own.
**Snow Adventure**
There was no clear path, but I thought I would be safe if I walked carefully. The wind was strong, pushing me as I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke, and I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had covered a gap between two rocks, leaving a thin layer that I fell through. I climbed out, feeling shaken and worried about what I would have done if the hole was deeper. I sat against a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think about my situation. In one hour, I had only gone half a mile. It was clear I needed to change my plan.
**Understanding Qualitative Research**
There are many books that try to help researchers with qualitative research. These books often talk a lot about how to collect data but not much about how to analyze it. Many people find data analysis mysterious. So, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to talk about how they analyze their data. The goal was to share ideas and understanding about data analysis, not to create a guidebook. This means making hidden methods more clear. Although this seems easy, it is actually quite difficult. We let our contributors present their work in different styles, including personal stories and more formal writing.

**Screen Learning**
A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look fierce. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting out a scene from a TV show he watched. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, and he didn't remember much. Many people are excited about learning through the internet and computers, but is learning from a screen really effective? One writer shared his experience with an interactive program he tried with his son. The father read the words carefully, but the son was more interested in playing with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned something. Television, as shown by my son and his noodles, is a medium that gives impressions and suggestions. Research shows that learning happens best in an environment where there is dialogue with teachers or parents. It needs guidance. Using new technology to teach children is fine, but formal education is still very important.
**Hollywood**
By 1918, most of the world's film-making had moved to Hollywood. Local people didn't like it at first, seeing their area of Los Angeles changed by these new people. But in the end, they accepted it because of success, which is very important in America. Success in Hollywood means making a lot of money at the box office. Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one: a film that might make a star, but must make money. In less than a century, Hollywood grew from a small village to a town as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. Physically, it has changed a lot: a hundred years ago, you would walk through orange groves to the village store. Yet, in some ways, it is still like a village - small and focused on one thing - films. People there talk about how much films have made, who is dating whom, and who is working on which project. Successful people often try to live somewhere else but still work in Hollywood. It is the place where almost everyone in show-business eventually goes.
**Photography**
Photography was created by nineteenth-century artists as a new art form. These artists wanted a lasting and accurate record of what they saw around them, and they found it. The new combination of light, lens, shutter, and a flat surface with light-sensitive chemicals made images that were more lasting and detailed than paintings. This worried other artists, and after their first excitement about the new images, art critics said that photography was not art. They believed that because photography depended on machines, it couldn't be a creative act. Despite the critics, photographers knew they had found a new way to express themselves. They used photography like other artists used brushes and pencils - to show their vision of the world and the people in it.
**Book Illustration**
During the time when book illustrations were in black and white, it was common for every children's book to have illustrations. This also included many novels for older readers, although this became less common as time went on. Children's publishing was very active, but it was often done with low budgets, leading to some routine and average work. However, the best artists always did their best work. The black-and-white archive is a mix of ordinary and great work, a great place for research or browsing. The best works are likely to be shown to the public again, either through reprints or new books about the artists, or in exhibitions of original books and drawings. There are signs that this is starting to happen, and people are beginning to appreciate this artistic period again. An enterprising publisher might see the potential for a series of classic children's book illustrations from this time, either in reprints or new editions using the original artwork.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**
Some time ago, a website talked about the risks of public check-ins, which are online announcements of where you are. The website's message was clear: you might think you are just telling the world, "Hey, I'm at this place," but you are also letting everyone know you are not at home. This made people more aware that sharing too much online can be risky. The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a global audience, offering possibilities like wealth and fame. So, we dive into the internet, sharing confessions, personal photos, and stories. But soon, we realize that the internet can be dangerous and confusing.
This might sound depressing, but don't worry. There is a way to navigate this future, thanks to a group of online pioneers. In the early days of the internet, they explored these challenges. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the challenges of being famous, all before social networking existed. These pioneers, the first bloggers, have already experienced what many of us are going through now. We should learn from their experiences to avoid making the same mistakes.
In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the "WWW," which was mostly used by students and scientists. The web was created at CERN in Switzerland to help researchers share their work. Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people were interested in his bold use of this new medium. Hall shared everything, and no topic was off-limits. His work was very open, but it also had a certain beauty that some might call art.
One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video titled "Dark Night." He shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped the blog, but the problem of sharing too much online continues. Sharing online is fun, but if you think it will make people like you more, you might be disappointed.
In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague sent her blog to the company's vice presidents, including some she had made fun of, and she lost her job. Experts call this the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online they wouldn't say in person. But our online and real lives are connected, and ignoring this can lead to big mistakes.
Armstrong's story ended well. She was upset and stopped blogging for a while, but she got married and started blogging again about her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. She learned that just because the web lets us say anything, it doesn't mean we should.

**Enough Sleep?**
Many people today feel tired all the time. In busy and rich countries, more people have trouble sleeping and feel anxious. In the USA, research shows that 40 million people have serious sleep problems. In Britain, some popular books have characters who can't sleep or are set in sleep labs. People are interested in sleep: how it works, its benefits, and sleep problems. A main concern is that people need more sleep. A top sleep researcher says, "People sleep less when they're busy. They wake up early to avoid traffic."
A sleep researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to settle at about eight hours of sleep. This shows they needed more sleep than they were getting.
In Europe, a university in the English Midlands studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise affects sleep, and the dangers of driving when tired. They find volunteers through student newspapers. Volunteers are paid and asked to change their sleep patterns. Dr. Louise Reyner reassures them: "Some worry because we put electrodes on their heads, but we can't see their dreams or thoughts." The lab focuses on physical effects.
In a dark room, there is a driving simulator. Volunteers come at 2 pm, when people naturally feel sleepy, after a short or no sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road seems endless, the sun is bright, and the air is warm. Many deny they will fall asleep. Dr. Reyner has a video of one trying not to sleep. At first, he is alert, but then he starts blinking slowly and nodding off. Each time, he wakes up suddenly, but the car has already gone off the road. Coffee might help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can make you a safe driver for over half an hour, even with no sleep. She suggests tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated gum for alertness. Shift workers could use them.
What do we know for sure about sleep? Humans, like other mammals, sleep in a daily cycle. During sleep, we go through four stages, from light to deep sleep. Dreams usually happen in the lightest sleep, and the brain stops the body from moving to prevent injuries. Beyond this, there are theories. Some say sleep repairs the body, restores muscles, or rests the brain. But these might also happen when awake and relaxed, so no one is sure. Scientists agree that women sleep half an hour longer than men and older people need less sleep, but they don't know why.
When asked about the purpose of sleep, some researchers say, "Sleep is a way to pass time safely." In the past, people may have slept differently. A history professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people had different sleep patterns. They went to bed at nine or ten, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for an hour, and then had a "morning sleep." This time was used for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poorest people benefited most from this quiet time. By the 17th century, with more artificial light, the rich started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made most people work longer hours in lit buildings, changing sleep patterns.
Outside Europe and America, the old sleep pattern was common until recently. In some non-western places, there are no strict bedtimes. People sleep for a few hours, then get up again. Continuous sleep is not possible due to noise, fire watching, and predators. It seems people everywhere need more sleep.

'We are talking about big boots here. Really big boots. I stood in my expensive cowboy boots on the rocks in the Arizona desert. Money was no problem. I wore the whole cowboy outfit, but I was not a cowboy. It wasn't working. I looked at the Arizona mountains and had to admit, I was not at home. I flew in from Denver just after dawn and thought I might look like a cowboy. But that feeling disappeared when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He wore a sweaty T-shirt, needed a shave, and was picking up a dirty bag. He saw my new cowboy boots, raised an eyebrow, and left without looking back.
I wished there was an outfit I could wear that made me feel like I belonged. I loved being a racing driver. I am addicted to it, and it's all I know how to do. But I don't do it anymore. I can't, even if I wanted to. I thought, looking at the mountains, what do I do now? A racing driver should have other plans for when he stops racing. I thought I did, but they disappeared.
How about being a commentator at the racetrack? 'We have fifteen former drivers in line for that job. We'll call you.' Or maybe selling classic cars? That idea lasted almost all winter, but nobody was buying old Ferraris, and Honda was changing its dealer list. So I left before there was nothing left.
Being an 'ex' anything is hard. How much do you want to hear about how I was almost the World Champion? Nobody wants to hear a story that ends in 'almost'. Even if I had been world champion, you would only listen for five minutes. Last year's champion is last year. I don't want sympathy, and I don't get any. Why should I? I had a good run, made money, and kept enough. But I miss driving those fast cars. I miss the danger and the excitement. I miss the people and the reporters who cared about what I said. Being famous, even a little, isn't all bad. Businessmen and politicians liked to say they knew me. Little boys wanted my autograph. And now that I don't drive a racing car... Only last week the phone rang twice. I have a lot of free time.
I looked up at the blue sky. No buzzards overhead. Maybe Arizona doesn't have buzzards. But a couple of little birds in a cactus were singing. I never thought the desert had songbirds. I realized that a fake cowboy in designer boots had a lot to learn.'

**Vancouver**
In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evening, people like to walk down the city streets, and if you join them, you will probably hear different languages. People come to Vancouver for its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and the mountains, clean and safe environment, and good education and job opportunities. Some people complain about how fast new buildings are being built, but the new people and growing tourism have helped the city grow. Locals used to call Vancouver 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Even though the name is not used much now, Vancouver is still a gateway.
**Putting Pen to Paper**
Journalists like me are usually not good at writing letters. Some say it's because we don't like writing for free, but I don't think that's true. It's more likely because we always try to make a big impact with our writing, so we lose the natural feeling of a letter. Real creative artists, who don't focus on the impact (even if they rewrite a lot), don't have this problem. I think the real test of an artist is how well they understand the effect of their words. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't think about how the mix of long words made them powerful, but it showed he was a great writer.
**Supermarket Opening**
In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A soap star, a disc jockey, or a minor royal would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open so often that celebrities are not needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can open it for free? Last week, waiting pensioners didn't care who opened the new Superbuy store, as long as they were first in line. One customer heard that the first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly, making those at the front feel proud and the latecomers feel envious.

**Citizen Kane**
When the film *Citizen Kane* came out in 1941, there was a lot of excitement around its release. It was delayed because the distributors were afraid of what William Randolph Hearst, who the film was supposedly about, might do to them. Even though the reviews were mostly very positive, the film was not a big success in theaters. It was television that made it popular again. *Citizen Kane* is perhaps the most inspiring film for people who want to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said that the film's success was because he didn't know what he could or couldn't do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to make a film about a newspaper owner who was like Hearst but also not like him, Welles knew he had found the perfect project for himself as both director and actor. He took the opportunity with great energy.
**Dermot and Carmel**
Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange that morning. He told her twice that he might be late and not to worry if he stopped by the golf club on his way home. He needed to talk to someone, and that was the best place to do it. Twice, Carmel nodded her head as if she hadn't really heard or understood him. "Will you be all right? What are you going to do today?" he asked. She smiled and said, "Funny you should ask that. I was just thinking that I had nothing to do all day, so I was going to walk downtown and look at the shops. I thought it was almost a sinful thing, just wasting the day." Dermot smiled back. "You're allowed to enjoy yourself. And as I said, if I'm late, I won't need anything to eat. So don't go to any trouble." "No, that's fine," she said.
**Title Race**
Tea boy? No, I'm a mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator.
Human nature can be very funny. A recent study showed that job titles cause jealousy and problems at work. A survey by a big recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees agree that titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey found that 70% of office workers would give up a pay raise for a more 'motivational' or 'professional' job title. If our desire for fancy titles is stronger than our desire for more money, we are in a difficult situation. Today, nobody wants to be called a subordinate. The titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just nicer ways to say the same thing.

'The Vienna Assignment I was in Vienna to take photographs. That was usually why I traveled. Photographs were more than my job; they were part of my life. The way light fell on a surface always sparked my imagination. A single picture could capture the essence of a time and place, a city, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect photograph. As long as I had film in my camera, there was a chance. Finish one roll, load another, and keep looking. That was my way. It had been for a long time. I almost succeeded once when a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well became popular worldwide. It was just luck, but they say you make your own luck. I went freelance after that, which seemed smart, but life outside photography took some wrong turns. The mid-nineties weren't as successful as I expected after my photo made it to the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more newsworthy. But I was still taking photographs and getting paid. It didn't seem bad to me. The assignment was unexpected. I had done the London photos for a picture book: Four Cities in Four Seasons - London, Paris, Rome, Vienna. It was a European project that paid me well to take photos in my home city in all seasons. I gave my own style to daffodils in Hyde Park and the heat haze in Piccadilly. I accepted that the best of my work might be ignored. It was just a picture book, not meant to challenge anyone's views. After a cold snap over Christmas, I handed in my London-in-winter photos and learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left the Vienna job. They offered me the role instead. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers. I was happy to go. Things at home weren't great. A week in snowy Vienna was a welcome change. They put me up at the Europa, in the heart of the old city. I had last been to Vienna with my wife for a busy summer weekend. It was hot and not very memorable. I hadn't taken many photos. Alone in a cold January, it was going to be different. I knew it as soon as I arrived and saw the city covered in snow. I was going to enjoy myself and take great pictures. The first day, I didn't even try. I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to feel the city's mood. The weather was set, frozen like the old empire's buildings. I hadn't seen Schussner's work for other seasons. I didn't want to. This was going to be my Vienna. A photograph is a moment, but you have to wait for it. So I waited and looked until I was ready. The next morning, I was out at dawn. Snow had fallen overnight, making Stephansplatz white and empty. I hadn't figured out how to capture the cathedral in one shot. Its spire was tall, but at ground level, it was massive. I might have to settle for a partial shot. In that weather, it could still be magical. Photography has always been magical. In the 19th century, people thought it was mysterious. Pictures develop and become clear on their own. Even when you know how it works, the mystery remains. Maybe that's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't surprise me.'

**Kinetic Art Rejoice**
Something amazing has happened at London's Hayward Gallery. It has become a place full of wonder, not because of a big, expensive show, but thanks to a unique exhibition about kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that involves movement. This exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art over the last 60 years. It shows that making art that moves or explores movement has been an important, though often unnoticed, part of creative work in the 20th century. Curator Guy Brett, who has studied kinetic art for a long time, has gathered a wonderful collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films. These are shown without many explanations, so visitors can enjoy discovering things on their own.
**David Hockney**
David Hockney's art is liked by many people, even those who usually don't care about art. This might be because his art is easy to understand or because it shows fun and relaxing scenes. Some people might even like him more for his interesting personality and humor, which make him popular in the news. Some critics think Hockney is not a great artist. However, others argue that he might seem less important because he is so popular, not because his work lacks quality. Hockney himself knows his limits and believes it's not fair to judge his work by an idea of greatness. He doesn't claim to be a great artist and knows that only time will tell how important his work is.
**Window-shopping - an art exhibition**
Recently, I have seen many contemporary art exhibitions, some good and some not. What bothers me are shows that try to push a certain idea, suggesting all the artists share the same view. Sometimes this works, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was different. With seven artists, I used a space in an empty warehouse for an exhibition called 'Window-shopping.' It was a collection of individual artworks that were only connected by being art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats moved around on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley's video camera experiment flickered on a monitor. These works didn't fit into a typical themed exhibition, but they worked together in their own way. I didn't make any big statements about contemporary art, but maybe there aren't any to make about an activity where artists set their own rules.
**Art History**
People who love paintings sometimes don't want to analyze them because they think it might ruin their enjoyment. Some say that art historians, who focus on theory, ignore the pleasure of looking at art and the creativity involved. This idea is like thinking that knowing how a dish is made takes away from its taste. Enjoying art doesn't mean we can't learn more about it. In fact, knowing more might make it more enjoyable. Pleasure is complex, and how we feel about art is influenced by the society we live in. While it's important to enjoy art instinctively, the idea that thinking about art takes away from its enjoyment is an old belief.

**Metals**
Stone Age people might have been interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting for a fish or just relaxing. One of our early ancestors might have found a shiny yellow stone and picked it up. It didn’t feel like a normal stone, but it looked nice. This is how gold might have become important to early people. Gold is soft and easy to shape, so it quickly became popular. Copper might have been found by accident too. Once people saw how useful copper tools were, they looked for copper ores and ways to get copper from them. This is how metalworking became an important skill for our ancestors.
**St Ives**
We were silent as we carried our bags down the winding, cobbled street to the center of town. We were bent over because of the strong wind and trying not to get wet from the icy waves hitting the promenade. The streets were empty, and the windows of every house by the water were closed tight against the storm. We had watched the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on the small train. As the grey skies got darker, visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car didn’t seem like a good idea anymore. I had convinced my friend to come with me by promising walks along the beautiful Cornish coast and cozy evenings by the fire.
**Computer Modelling**
The problem with studying the past is that it is gone. The people who lived in times of peace and hard times are long dead. The reasons they settled in one place or moved to another, and how they formed families, villages, and cities, are forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We cannot watch the past like a movie. But maybe we can. Computer modelling lets us recreate ancient landscapes and fill them with virtual communities. These digital people have some needs and abilities like real humans. We can set rules for them and change things like rainfall or population to see how this digital culture reacts.

**Vervet Monkeys**
Cheney and Seyfarth studied a group of vervet monkeys. One day, the dominant male monkey saw a strange male monkey in nearby trees. The stranger wanted to join the group, which could mean trouble for the dominant male. To keep the stranger away, the dominant male used a clever trick. When the stranger tried to come closer, the dominant male gave an alarm call that meant a leopard was nearby. The stranger quickly went back to his trees. This happened several times. But then, the dominant male made a mistake. He gave the alarm call while he was calmly walking in the open, showing there was no real danger.
**What Cats Catch**
In the English village of Felmersham, people collected what their cats caught. Over one year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals.
