Humans have a special ability: we can communicate with each other using language. Language is so important in our lives that it is hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will probably start talking. Even when alone, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to talk naturally, just like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders did not learn web-making from a special spider school; it is something they just know how to do.
**Climate and Weather**
Climate and weather, created by the air around us, have a big impact on where animals and plants live. Climate can change the look of a place. For example, warm and wet weather all year helps tropical jungles grow, which have many different species. On the other hand, cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather patterns, which together make up the climate, happen because large amounts of air move and mix. The air is always moving because the earth spins, and the air does not move as fast as the earth. The sun is another important reason for air movement.
**Coffee**
As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks and make coffee, which worried me. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I spent several days learning how to make coffee and how to clean the espresso machine. I also learned how to make a perfect cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized making good coffee was harder than it looked, and I thought I might be moved to cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. "Making coffee is both an art and a science," he said, "and you need time to learn how to do it well."

**Art on TV**
Why does television often fail with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture should be easy for the camera to show. The camera can show a whole artwork and then zoom in to see details. But there are few TV series that show both the joy and complexity of looking at art. A good example of this problem is Robert Hughes's series, "American Visions." Hughes is a trustworthy critic with a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would focus on great artworks. Instead, it was about how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a risk-taker. Metals are less regulated than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Risk-taking is a big part of the industry. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. But now, free-trade economists who said the market would keep the price of scarce metals stable have found the opposite. More minerals are being extracted, and the cost of raw materials is going down. Considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas. They stretch from Florida past the Tropic of Cancer to Cuba. Each island has its own personality and offers something special. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If your room doesn't include one, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis. Or, you can rent a boat if you want to go on your own. Sailing is the most popular way to travel here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm, protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. It's not only at sea that you find treasures. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes of Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay sparkle.

'Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK
The Bamboo Bike Club, run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, offers a course where you can build your own custom bamboo bike frame. It's a fun weekend activity in Hackney Wick, east London. On a Saturday morning, the Bamboo Bike Club is busy with the sound of machinery. Bamboo bikes are becoming popular again, thanks to companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire. However, these bikes can be expensive, with ready-made frames costing around $2,995 or £1,868.
James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to create a business that offers bamboo bikes at a price that more cyclists can afford. They realized they wanted to share the joy of making a bike, not just sell frames. So, they started the Bamboo Bike Club, which is more like a community than a company. James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer, but they run monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame.
On the first day of the course, you learn how to choose strong bamboo and make strong joints. You start by gluing the bamboo tubes together to form the bike's frame. Metal tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. James and Ian help you with every step, making sure everything is done correctly. If you make a mistake, you can try again with a new piece of bamboo.
On Sunday, you wrap the joints with hemp and glue them with epoxy resin to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other parts. The bamboo bike is strong and can last a long time. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested one off-road for three months without breaking it.
Bamboo bikes may look a bit rough compared to professional frames, but they are unique. They are great for a relaxed ride. James's bike is light and smooth, making it fun to ride. The best part is the price, which is less than £500.'

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she found a manuscript by an unknown psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She saw the title and knew it would be a bestseller. She was right. Dr. Gray is now very rich, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book on communication between men and women is very popular in the self-help industry. This industry is growing and claims to help people improve their lives. It also benefits from people's desires to get better and supports the publishing world in New York. In Britain, the self-help genre is also becoming popular, with many books being published. However, many self-help books are rejected for being too similar to others or too specific. Editors look for books that can sell well. They ask questions like, "How promotable is the author?" and "Is the idea universal?" Dione Reverend says that a catchy title is very important for a book's success.
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an agreement between the writer and the reader that the truth is being told. However, this is not always the case. Writers might leave out things they find too embarrassing or unimportant. Sometimes, they might change the truth to make the story more interesting or to better show their true self. Some writers might even call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. This can happen without any bad intentions.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
Detective stories became popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. They often show the conflicts in society. In these stories, a crime represents human desires like lust or greed. Solving the crime shows how society can return to normal. In Hammett's stories, society is shown as corrupt. The detective and the criminal understand each other. The detective is both a part of the law and a bit of a criminal. He is both a crook and a competitor. Sometimes, the detective feels connected to the criminal, and sometimes he is very eager to catch them because of this connection.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is a well-known science writer. He believes that to write well about science, you need to understand the culture of science. Only scientists can present science well because they know the community and its rules. Gould advises never to underestimate the reader. You can make the language simpler, but you should not change the main ideas. If readers feel they are being talked down to, they will lose interest.

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers to visit during lunch, the air feels very cold. To handle this summer's very high temperatures, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, when it's quiet, the gym feels as cold as the Arctic. This is an example of how people often use too much air-conditioning. It has become a big part of work and leisure, showing how humans can control or change the climate. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and air, and have thicker walls that keep out heat during the day and release it at night. These ideas might seem simple, but they can work well and reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, people are again interested in sundials. Sundials are tools that tell time by the position of the sun. A hundred years ago, they were important for keeping time accurately. But as clocks and watches improved, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people are taking them seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks they are special because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts working. They are calm, romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
I used to think china-painting was only for very skilled people. I once saw older women at an arts and crafts show painting teacups with perfect flowers. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I thought they must have been practicing for many years or had a special talent. So, I wondered who would join a china-painting class. Would beginners also be very talented? But the class was not scary at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers on teacups as quickly as I remembered.

'The Wrong Country Uncle chose a package holiday for them at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport, twelve nights in Venice, the fairyland city, at the Pensione Concordia. When Keith and Dawne went to the travel agency to book, the clerk explained that the other people in the package were a school group from the south coast, all learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either at the travel agency or at the check-in desk, or in a computer, a small mistake happened. Dawne and Keith ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland. At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in the yellow-and-red Your-Kind-of-Holiday uniform. She called them by name, checked their tickets, and said everything was fine. An hour later, they were surprised to hear elderly people on the plane talking in North of England accents. Keith thought there must have been a cancellation, or maybe the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered two drinks, and then two more. 'The coach will take us on,' a stout woman with glasses said when they landed. 'Stay together now.' There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but when the coach arrived at its destination, Keith thought that must be what it was. As they got off the coach, it was almost midnight: tired and dirty from travel, they didn't feel like questioning their right to the beds they were offered. But the next morning, when they realized they were being offered the beds for their whole holiday, they became worried. 'We have the lake, and the water birds,' the receptionist explained with a smile. 'And we can take the steamer to Interlaken.' 'A mistake has been made,' Keith told the man, trying to stay calm. He could hear his wife's nervous breathing next to him. 'We were supposed to be in Venice. At the Pensione Concordia.' 'I do not know the name, sir. This is Switzerland.' 'A coach is supposed to take us on. An official said so on the plane. She was here last night, that woman.' 'Your group is booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. To change now, sir, if you have changed your minds -' 'We haven't changed our minds. There's been a mistake.' The receptionist shook his head. He didn't know about a mistake. 'The man who made the booking,' Dawne said, 'was bald, with glasses and a moustache.' She gave the name of the travel agency in London. 'Some problem, have we?' a woman said, smiling at Keith. She was the stout woman he thought was an official. They'd seen her talking to the yellow-and-red girl at Gatwick. On the plane, she'd walked up and down the aisle, smiling at people. 'My name is Franks,' she said now. 'I'm married to the man with the bad leg.' 'Are you in charge, Mrs. Franks?' Dawne asked. 'Only we're in the wrong hotel.' Again she gave the name of the travel agency and described the bald-headed clerk, mentioning his glasses and moustache. Keith interrupted her. 'It seems we got into the wrong group. We reported to the Your-Kind-of-Holiday girl and left it all to her.' 'We should have known when they weren't from Dover,' Dawne added. 'We heard them talking about Darlington.' Keith made an impatient sound. He wished she'd let him do the talking. 'We noticed you at Gatwick,' Keith said. 'We knew you were in charge.' 'And I noticed you. I counted you, although I guess you didn't see me doing that. Now, let me explain. There are many places Your-Kind-of-Holiday sends its clients, many different holidays at different prices. There are, for example, villa holidays for adventurous people under thirty-five. There are treks to Turkey, and treks for singles to the Himalayas.' 'Now, what I am trying to say is that all tickets and labels are similar, the yellow with the two red bands.' Mrs. Franks suddenly laughed. 'So if you just followed other people with the yellow-and-red label, you might think you could end up in a wildlife park! But of course,' she added kindly, 'that couldn't happen in a million years.' 'We're not meant to be in Switzerland,' Keith insisted. 'Well, let's just see, shall we?' Unexpectedly, Mrs. Franks turned and went away, leaving them standing. The receptionist was no longer behind the desk. The sound of typing could be heard. 'She seems quite kind,' Dawne whispered, 'that woman.' Keith wasn't listening. He tried to remember everything that had happened: giving the girl the tickets, sitting down to wait, then the girl leading them to the plane, and then the pilot's voice welcoming them, and the air hostess with the smooth black hair checking everyone's seat belt. 'Nice to have some young people along,' an elderly man's voice interrupted Keith's thoughts. 'Nottage is the name.' The old man's wife was with him, both looking like they were in their eighties. They'd slept like logs, she said, best night's sleep they'd had for years, which of course was due to the lakeside air. 'That's nice,' Dawne said. Keith walked out of the reception area and Dawne followed him. In front of the hotel, they didn't say to each other that there was an irony in what had happened. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they ended up in a package tour of elderly people when the whole point of the holiday was to escape the needs and demands of the elderly. In his bossy way, Uncle had said so himself when they'd tried to persuade him to come with them.'

'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American business leaders are looking at the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model of good management. Eluned Price reports. Many people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a general idea of what he did. In America, however, he is only now becoming well-known. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton 'an Antarctic explorer whose achievements went unnoticed for most of the 20th century,' which might be an exaggeration. But now Americans are very interested in him. Biographies and stories about the voyage of the Endurance are being made and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a film about Shackleton's life. Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his actions and learn lessons in leadership and communication from him. They even talk about 'speaking Shackleton.' Shackleton, with his reindeer sleeping bag and blubber-stove, has become a model for modern management consultants. Jim MacGregor, a managing partner in New York, chose Shackleton as a role model years ago. His company deals with communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises. For example, when a company's plant explodes or when half the workforce has to be let go. Shackleton once worked in public relations for a Glasgow steel company, but it might be hard to see how surviving on albatross meat in freezing temperatures relates to handling a business crisis. 'Even if a company manages its crises well, it can still cause problems by communicating poorly,' says MacGregor. 'Shackleton is a model for management because of his leadership and communication skills. He had his values in order. He was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of Shackleton's most interesting decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This decision showed his credibility for the next expedition: the lives of his men were most important.' This refers to Shackleton's 1908 expedition to the South Pole when, 97 miles short of their goal, with supplies running low and limited time to return to their ship, Shackleton made the brave decision to turn back. In a crisis, says MacGregor, people want to know someone is in charge. While managers today might avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take it. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and was finally crushed. When it sank, Shackleton told his men, 'we should all eventually reach safety if you continue to do your best and trust me.' From the diaries and accounts kept by his men, it is clear that Shackleton was always in charge. 'Shackleton thought everything through, planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions,' says MacGregor. 'He was adaptable, willing to let go when something was lost and start anew. We've built a set of principles here that Shackleton illustrates. Clients can relate to his story without feeling criticized.' Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. 'One of the hardest things to do in desperate situations is to do nothing, especially in America, where people want quick solutions,' says MacGregor. 'If you buy bonds and guess wrong on the interest rates, you hang in there and eventually you'll get your money back. To "fix it" and sell would mean a big loss. Also, don't be afraid to change your plans if they're not working. If a new product is bad, don't keep selling it.' Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, saying if he didn't wear them, he would throw them overboard. Someone else remembered him doing the same with a biscuit when they were starving on the 1905 expedition: 'He said he'd leave it in the snow. Millions of pounds couldn't have bought that biscuit.' As Caroline Alexander, author of Endurance, says: 'The public's interest in heroic efforts is growing. Shackleton shows that there is nothing heroic happening now. Everything else fades away, and he stands as the true example of the ideals we miss today.'

'Finding Food in Madagascar's Forests In the forests of Madagascar, there is a primate called the aye-aye that lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye search for insect larvae by making holes in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to gnaw into the wood and its long, thin third finger to reach and scoop out the insects. Although scientists described the aye-aye's feeding habits over a hundred years ago, they have only recently learned how it finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of two male aye-ayes, Nosferatu and Poe, a female, Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to see if they found insects by looking for signs on the wood, like holes where insects might have entered. Dr. Erickson gave the aye-ayes logs with several small holes. Some holes led to spaces with mealworms, while others were empty. The aye-ayes went directly to the holes with food, showing they did not need to see the holes to find the insects. Dr. Erickson tested if the aye-ayes used smell or sound to find the insects. Even when the smell was blocked, and the insects were dead and silent, the aye-ayes still found them. So, how did they do it? Dr. Erickson found that the aye-ayes could sense empty spaces in the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its middle finger and listens with its large ears. Dr. Erickson thinks the aye-aye uses echo-location, like a bat, to find hollow spaces. It might also hear insects moving when disturbed by the tapping. The idea that the aye-aye takes the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting. However, there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also look for insects in wood, so the woodpecker's role might not be empty. The aye-aye is like a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat combined. It also acts like a squirrel because its teeth grow continuously, and it has been seen in the wild gnawing through nut shells and using its long finger to get the nut meat.'

'Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives Most of us have photos of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries give us small, incomplete glimpses, and family stories are often only half remembered. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do it. We might leave videos instead of photos, but they are still two-dimensional. Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people, creating a hardback book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if wanted. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary ones. The idea came to her when she talked to her family and realized how much of the past was disappearing. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "People say they do it for their children or for the future, but they also enjoy it themselves." The promise of privacy helps people be honest. "I had the confidence to be honest," says a 62-year-old man who made and lost a fortune before making another. "I was surprised at what came out. There were painful things, like my divorce." "I did it for my family, so they could learn something, but I haven't let my children read it yet. They were hurt by things in my life, and there are details I don't want them to know now. If they insist, I'll let them. But I'd rather they read it after I'm gone." He also saw patterns from his childhood that led to repeated mistakes. Ms. Renier has noticed this in others too. "It's amazing how many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "Things parents said or did affect them for the rest of their lives. They marry people their parents would like, or do the opposite to rebel." "Many disappointments come out. Even sixty years later, people regret or resent things that were never resolved with their parents. There is no age of reason. If people had problems in their youth, they still have them in middle age. They try to impress a parent who wasn't impressed, and if that fails, some want to say 'I can't stand my mother.'" Ms. Renier is more of a recorder than an investigator. "It's not for the public, and I'm not there to be nosy. People sometimes tell me things and then say, 'I'm not sure if that should go in.' I include it anyway—they can remove it when they see the draft. But generally, people want to be honest, with all their flaws." "It's not vanity publishing. It's not people saying 'I've had such an interesting life, the world needs to know.' Things are changing faster than ever, and we are losing sight of the past. It's a way to connect with our ancestors because families don't sit together as much anymore. People want a little immortality." Each book involves up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story, rearranging the timeline and interpreting. Modern technology allows her to produce everything except the binding with its gold lettering: you can choose your own color and title. Fascinating to the private audience for whom each book is made, the results are not about revealing secrets at any cost. Ms. Renier organizes her material logically and writes well, so the final content is as good as its subject. The book looks high-quality and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost, due to the time involved, stops many people. "I thought it would be a more affordable product," she says. "But the people I've worked with have all been well-off, readers of Harpers & Queen, where I advertise. They're the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted for their descendants."'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of Greek and Roman sculpture casts in the world, with over six hundred pieces. Remember, nothing here is original. All sculptures are accurate copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a special gallery with great natural light. Plaster casts have many benefits: sculptures that were originally together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together as they were meant to be. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery showing different photography exhibitions. We often run courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, including a Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (aged 12 to 16) improve their skills with our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photographic books, magazines, and materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**
The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world and from all geological ages. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, that of Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728), with nearly 10,000 rare specimens in their original 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, added a lot to the collections, creating an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, showing major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern use.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**
There are over 400,000 air photographs in the collection, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos throughout Great Britain. The photos are interesting as they show the landscape and human activity from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. The photos cannot be borrowed, but copies can be bought and usually take about a month to make.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world and is a unique tourist attraction. You can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. By making resin copies, called facsimiles, the center preserves the originals while allowing people to enjoy brass rubbing. Brass plates, used as memorials instead of statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many were destroyed in revolutions, but most of the remaining brasses are in Britain, and the Cambridge Centre has a wide range of examples.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
**A. The Theatre Director**
I have had 35 years of being around small children because of my unusual personal life. I have loved every minute of it. This morning, I fed the baby, and for me, that is what being a father is all about. I am very lucky with my children. We all love opera, theatre, books, and music. This creates a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up, and I am more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in physical violence. I have slapped my children in anger, but I don't support it. I may not have been a very attentive father, but I have always tried to be available. I am here if they need me, but I let them call me. If you start chasing them to ask why they haven't been in touch, you make them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.
**B. The Advertising Executive**
I was young when my children were born, only about 25, and I found the responsibilities difficult. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I value. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and clothes. This has been very helpful for running the agency. I have never felt out of touch. When they were young, I was busy with my business, so I missed some things like their first concerts and sports days. I feel sad about that, but now I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and come to parties and advertising awards with us without feeling shy. I think it helps that I do something they find glamorous and interesting.
**C. The Politician**
My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more politically active, time became a problem. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if there are facilities for the kids to come with me. This way, they know what I do when I am not with them, and there is no feeling of Daddy disappearing. I have noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we are all realizing the need to involve our children in our lives.
**D. The Writer**
My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were young, so I had to think a lot about being a father. I made big efforts to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next door to each other so the kids could come and go as they wanted, but I think they found that confusing. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a very good father. I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too liberal. I think I could have been more organized. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. In that way, your kids never leave you.
**E. The TV Presenter**
I was ready for kids. I was 30, met my wife, and we had a lovely house. We thought, "Why keep spending money on new sofas when we could have a child instead?" Having my daughter Betty has made me understand who I am. You feel special when you have a child, and you are, but you also become just one more parent in a long line of parents. It's a great equalizer. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but one look at her makes it go away. A baby's smile is the best way to make a grown man melt.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**
A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
This is a play by Marlowe about a powerful warrior. It is very long, but in Terry Hands' version, it becomes exciting and fast. Antony Sher plays the main role and is very impressive. He does stunts like somersaulting and sliding down a rope while speaking. Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)
B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by Michael Wall moved from Manchester to London. The first part is about two married couples talking in a garden, creating a tense feeling. The second part shows the impact of illness. Michael Wall was a talented writer who died young. Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)
C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche, an Irish playwright, wrote this play set in Wexford. It talks about the decline of the fishing industry with strong characters and emotions. The play is a bit slow at times but ends powerfully. Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)
D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a traditional thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play writers who want to kill each other. The story is familiar but has clever twists. Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)
E. **The Alchemist**  
Director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about tricksters. The show was first seen in Stratford and is now at the Barbican. The actors give great performances as the con-artists. Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)
F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James directs this comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society. It was successful in Edinburgh and is now in London. The play is stylish and well-acted. Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)
G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a version of Beauty and the Beast set in London. It has a beautiful score by John Pattison and celebrates romantic love. It is a charming show. Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)
H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy is not very good, but it has excellent comic performances by Ron Cook and Anton Lesser. Most of the other actors seem uncomfortable. Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)
I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another play by Granville Barker, now touring. It is about a lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son. It is a wonderful play. Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)

**Hide and Seek** by Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game by watching a suspicious bookshop. She is surprised to see her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him to turn her against her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes intense. She is trapped in the basement of an old house. This book shows family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always protectors. A powerful read.
**Backtrack** by Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, discover that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915, where eight people died. They use different viewpoints and documents like maps and first-hand accounts to understand what happened. This clever and complex novel requires close attention.
**Pigeon Summer** by Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer doesn't fit into her family or male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons. When he leaves to find work, Mary takes care of the pigeons and wins prizes, despite conflicts with her mother. Set in 1930, this story shows that there are different kinds of cleverness. Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
Rose, a mature woman, rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage to escape her materialistic life. She finds a fierce cat and strange items that explain Yaxley's disappearance. The locals become hostile, putting her family at risk. By the end, the danger is controlled, but Rose is troubled by her son's actions. A gripping story.
**Someone's Mother is Missing** by Harry Mazer  
Sam, from a poor family, is impressed by his rich cousin Lisa. When Lisa's world falls apart, Sam helps her find balance. They both learn about reality and family value. The story is slow in parts but has gentle humor and shows the growing closeness between the teenagers. It appeals to both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium** by Barry Faville  
Robbie works as a gardener for Stanley, an elderly man. At first, she finds him interesting, but later she is disturbed by what he keeps in his aquarium. The story takes a thrilling turn while exploring character and relationships. It is unusual and compelling.
**Dodger** by Libby Gleeson  
Mick's troubled personal life and school experiences are told through flashbacks, letters, and notes. He struggles with low self-esteem and negative expectations. He finds confidence through a school play and a supportive teacher. Highly recommended, though it is a sad and emotional read, especially at the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing their ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, it looked like a regular airplane. The pilot told the young passengers it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964, similar to a Boeing 707 passenger plane. But inside, it was different. The 13 students from Europe and America were about to have an unforgettable flight. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, except for a few at the back where the nervous students sat. For a year, they competed with other students to join this flight, offered by the European Space Agency. They had to suggest creative experiments to do in weightless conditions. The best ideas won a place on this special flight, which was like an extraordinary roller-coaster ride.
For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly like a giant bird, going up and down. The goal was to create a weightless state at the top of each curve. At 3,000 meters, the pilot cut the engines, and the plane went higher on its own before gravity pulled it down again. In those few seconds between going up and falling, everything inside became weightless, and the students felt closer to the moon than the Earth.
The plane took off smoothly, but soon the pilot made it climb at a 45-degree angle for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and bodies floated in the cabin. Then the engines stopped, and we were weightless almost immediately. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence: the floor felt like a trampoline, and one step sent us towards the ceiling. We floated aimlessly; directions like left or right, up or down, no longer made sense. Only gravity helps us understand where we are.
After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity returned suddenly, and some students landed with a bump. After the first curve, some students felt sick thinking about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves gave ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They used a device to turn it belly-down with radio controls. During the next curve, another student accidentally landed on it.
Nearby, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joins are affected by no gravity, thinking about future space stations. Another team from Utah State University looked at making solar sails from thin liquid films in sunlight. They tried to make these films in microgravity, hoping satellites could use solar sails like yachts use wind.
After two hours of flying up and down, breakfast felt unstable, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This feeling would last a long time. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I wanted to become an astronaut before, but now I want to even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of "Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology." He talks about a unique time in his life when he didn't experience any summers. He traveled to New Zealand every summer in the UK, which is winter in New Zealand, and spent nine winters in a row there. He enjoyed this because he likes winter.
His parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land in New Zealand for him and his siblings to take care of. His mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, they would always have a connection to New Zealand, where their father grew up. They found a plot of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was suitable for planting trees.
Jonathon was excited about the idea because he loved working with land. He had spent a year in Australia working on farms, so planting trees sounded great to him. He started planting in 1968, and by 1972, he and his siblings had planted trees on the entire 70 acres.
The winter of 1968 in New Zealand was very rainy, but Jonathon remembers it as a happy time. Every morning, he faced the challenge of getting ready to plant trees in the rain. He worked with an experienced tree-planter, which helped him learn. They used a planting bag to carry the trees and had to make sure the lines were straight when planting.
Jonathon enjoyed the hard physical work, and it made him fit. Planting became automatic, and he developed a rhythm. This allowed him to think deeply about life and nature, which influenced his future work.
He has returned to New Zealand four times to see the trees grow, which has been satisfying. He worries about natural disasters affecting the trees but is happy they are now 20 years old and healthy.
In 1984, Jonathon took time off from teaching to return to New Zealand alone for three months. He wrote his first book, "Seeing Green," in a small cabin on the tree farm. He feels a strong connection to the land and believes it is a powerful bond between people and the earth.

**BRINGING UP BADGERS**
"What now?" I thought when a helper handed me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an "open farm" six years ago, and we are known for caring for orphaned animals. The noise from the box was strange, like a mix between a cackle and a bark. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their fur was soft like velvet, and they had milky-colored eyes on their black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and live underground. If orphaned, they usually die of starvation. These three were found by builders who accidentally dug into their home. The mother was found dead with her babies still feeding from her. The cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing their fleas, I took them into the kitchen and placed them by the stove for warmth. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to mimic their mother licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, they were fed every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though unsteadily. They seemed happy with each other and a heated pad as a substitute "mum."
Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was lethargic, though he was eating normally. I should have acted immediately, but I didn't realize the importance. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet's post-mortem showed Willow died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat, even with antibiotics. I was sad about losing Willow but continued caring for the others. Six days later, a local farmer brought me another male cub, abandoned by its mother. The area had been disturbed too much, and the cub was cold and hungry. We named him Willow II. He was about two weeks younger than the females and difficult to feed. I had to move the bottle's teat around in his mouth to get him to drink. After 10 minutes, he would finally latch on. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and then anything. Willow II was different. He struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready for other foods.
At nearly five months old, they were eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat earthworms, beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and plant shoots or roots. My badgers were better off than others that year because the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms. By August, the cubs became nocturnal and went for walks at dusk or night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they played and chased each other. As "human badgers," we joined in the fun. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek didn't and often got bruised. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely expanding their territory to find food, as badgers are territorial and can kill intruders. We were warned they might enter our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we secured the gate with sheet metal.
The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response was so positive that we started a project to build a sett on the farm for them. With advice, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate facing their usual path. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side for viewing. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they preferred the sett over walks. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company, Badgerline, sponsored part of it, and local firms donated materials. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Later, I checked on them and saw three badgers asleep in their chambers.
These days, I don't walk with them as often, especially since they wake up at midnight. We see Primrose occasionally, as she joined a neighboring sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still greet us before running off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have accepted.

**In Search of True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet**
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was studying 'compass variations' during his sea voyages on the ship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors couldn't correct their compasses, making it hard to navigate the oceans accurately.
Halley was one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time. He sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic. The first trip was stopped due to problems with the crew, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he published a chart showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. This chart was very useful to sailors for over a century until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made it outdated.
Dr. Clark, who loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the same route. He needs to raise £70,000 for the journey, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first cross-Antarctica expedition, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist's life. Halley was not only an astronomer but also did research in geophysics and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous work, Principia Mathematica.
Dr. Clark's expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will have scientific value. He will take the same measurements Halley did, but with better instruments. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the international geomagnetic reference field, a model of Earth's magnetic field. Dr. Clark will use global positioning satellites to find true north, which is necessary for measuring the magnetic field's direction.
The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the expedition. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean. Ground-based measurements are also useful for comparison.
Halley's journey was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian made a naval captain for this purpose. Dr. Clark has the experience needed for this journey. He spent two years in Antarctica, worked with the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey, and sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.
Dr. Clark is committed to this project, saying, 'I am prepared to give up my life for eight months to do this.' He feels a strong purpose from Halley's life and work.

**POWER DRESSING**
Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens. This behavior puzzled Charles Darwin because, in a world where survival is tough, it seemed strange that birds would evolve such extravagant tails. Darwin believed that animals evolved through natural selection, meaning the strongest and smartest survive. However, the peacock's tail seemed to be a disadvantage, so Darwin suggested another idea called 'sexual selection'. He thought females chose mates based on beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He believed that if peahens chose the most beautiful males, there must be a good reason. The males might have some hidden quality that helps them survive. Today, scientists like Marion Petrie from the Open University are studying the peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers. They want to know if peahens really prefer males with the showiest tails and if these males have other advantages.
Observations show that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails. However, it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways. Some scientists, like William Hamilton from Oxford University, think that showy males might be healthier and have fewer parasites. But this hasn't been proven in the Whipsnade peacocks yet.
This year, Dr. Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive and less attractive males to see if the former grow faster or are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is practical.
There's another theory by R A Fisher called 'Fisher's Runaway'. It suggests that if females start preferring males with slightly better tails, over generations, this preference and the trait will grow stronger. This could explain the peacock's tail and support Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake'.

'THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS The best boat design should mix old and new, says Tom Cunliffe. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of beautiful yachts with new technology. Most of them come from a big change in boat design 25 years ago. My boat, however, is on a quiet creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. You might think I am a romantic person. Maybe I am, but I don't think so. This boat uses old boat design ideas, but modern technology made it easier to build. However, modern technology often makes sailing too easy and takes away the real experience of being at sea. I don't think sailors should suffer, but I like my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable beds. Why go sailing if everything is automatic? Sometimes, dealing with the sails is part of the adventure. Also, why move the steering from the back to the middle of the boat? This change makes more room inside, but I believe a boat should feel like a boat, not a house. When I bought my old boat, Hirta, the previous owner said it had comfort but no luxury. Hirta taught me he was right. It had heavy sails, no pumped water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, it was the nicest boat I have ever sailed. But old boats need a lot of care. After a back injury, I knew I had to sell Hirta. I couldn't find a good new boat, so I decided to build one. The Westerman has never let me down. Nigel Irens, the designer, and Ed Burnett, his assistant, used computers to design it, but Irens first drew it on a napkin. Then he made a model, like in the old days. We looked at the model and then used the computer to make changes. The final design was perfect. The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. She looks timeless, sails smoothly, and her inside, made from old pine wood, feels peaceful. This is because she was designed as a sailing boat first, not as a place to live. This old method works well. She shows that you don't need to follow new trends to be happy and that history can teach us valuable lessons. Made from wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. So, she has all the benefits of a modern boat but looks and feels like a traditional one.'

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**
I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors are very good, and I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and facials. The staff are friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to add a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds or walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt happier and more energetic. I left feeling great and full of energy. This is a perfect break for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**
The calm atmosphere of this stately home was clear from the moment I arrived. The Hall has a beautiful library and a conservatory. When you arrive, you get a medical check-up, including weight and blood pressure. We were called patients, which was strange because I am healthy. But they found a shoulder problem during the check-up, and the fitness instructor helped me with it. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight without fasting, but I had a headache on the second day. My meals included grapefruit for breakfast, salads for lunch, and fruit with yoghurt for dinner. If you are not on a diet, you eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty. You get a massage or water therapy every other day. Extra treatments are well-priced. - Liz Gregory
**C. CAREYS MANOR**
Careys is not a health farm but a lovely old manor with log fires and a big lounge. If you are watching your weight, you might skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and desserts. Luckily, there is a gym and pool to work off the calories. There is also a spa bath, steam room, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture and exercises. Careys is comfortable and luxurious. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around. - Beverly D'Silva
**D. CLIVEDEN**
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, and horse riding. There are beautiful walks and gardens on the 376-acre estate. Waldo's restaurant has amazing food. The dinner menu is long, and the meal was wonderful, especially the sticky-toffee pudding. I went to bed happy! The next morning, I spent time in the gym before my next meal. I enjoyed a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty options if you want to use them before enjoying a meal at Waldo's. - Kay Letch
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It's delicious but has 360 calories, which is not good if you want to lose weight. The aromatherapy massage is also great. I chose relaxing oils and fell asleep twice during the massage. The place is modern and well-run, with many therapists and beauty rooms. They offer many treatments, like manicures and facials. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to friends and singles. I would love to visit here once a month. - Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much genetically. We are still more than 98% the same as chimps. This means that what makes us different from animals is a recent development. Our ability to make art and do other things we consider uniquely human must come from a small part of our genes. This is a big responsibility for just a few genes. 
Studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were unique to humans are not. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings show that there are few absolute differences between us and animals, except for art.
If human art comes from a unique genetic gift, it's interesting that our ancestors didn't make art for most of the 7 million years since they split from chimps. The earliest art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these don't last over time. Clear evidence of human art, like cave paintings and statues, only appears around 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.
Some people say human art is different because it is non-utilitarian (not useful for survival), made for aesthetic pleasure, and learned rather than instinctive. Let's look at these ideas. First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." Human art doesn't help us survive or pass on genes, unlike most animal behaviors. For example, birdsong helps birds defend territory or attract mates, which helps pass on genes. By this measure, human art is different.
The second idea is that only humans make art for aesthetic pleasure. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during breeding season, so they probably don't sing just for pleasure. Again, human art seems unique.
The third idea is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Different human groups have different art styles that are learned, not inherited. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. Some birds, however, are born knowing their species' song. It's like a French baby raised in Japan suddenly singing the French national anthem without learning it.
Human art changes quickly. Geese honked 2,000 years ago just like they do today, but human art styles change fast. Even a casual museum visitor can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, they might mistake paintings by two chimpanzees, Congo and Betsy, for human art. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. In 1957, their paintings were shown in London, and many were sold, which some human artists can't claim.
These chimpanzee paintings blur the line between human art and animal activities. Like human art, they weren't made for practical reasons but for the painter's satisfaction. You might say human art is different because it's meant to communicate, but some famous human art was also made for personal satisfaction.

**A Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on earth that people have not explored much. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. Children's stories used to be about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance on their journeys into the unknown. These days, you don't find such people in stories or in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's big adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while sitting calmly at home with his family. The team he led included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts on the area, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous and could have ruined the expedition.
This group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's least friendly desert, and Charles Blackmore wrote an interesting book about their journey. At the time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to prove something. 'I always thought I'd spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was, outside all that. It was a big risk. Tina, my wife, was very worried that I wouldn't come back because nobody had ever done that route; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us.'
Anyone reading his amazing story of that crossing will wonder why he used the word 'kind'. The team suffered a lot: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst and dehydration, and the loss of some of their precious water supply. 'But', Blackmore explains, 'when we were at the limits of our endurance and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we managed to find some. We didn't experience the Taklamakan's famous sandstorms. And we never faced the raw, biting desert cold that would have stopped us completely. That's not to say that we weren't fighting against problems the whole time. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were very hard to climb, for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us.'
'What drove me on more than anything else was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Neither our budget nor time allowed one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared of my physical ability to do it. I remember day one -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We've got to do it now!" At that moment, I was a very scared man.'
If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked for 1,000 kilometers, you're not going to give up. You've endured so much; you've got so much behind you. We were very thin, but very muscular and strong despite our physical exhaustion. My body was well-toned, and my legs were like pistons. I could walk over anything.'
In the middle of the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon, and thinking of his family. How aware was he of the difficulty it must have been for them? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace with himself. When I have doubts about myself now, I go back to the image of the desert and think, well, we managed to pull that together. As a personal achievement, I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I've done. Yet in terms of a lifetime's achievement, I think of my family and the happiness we share -- against that measure, the desert does not compare.'
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I yearn for the challenge -- for the open spaces -- the resolve of it all. We were lifted by the sense of purpose. I find it difficult now to be part of the sameness of modern life.'

Susan Harr felt overwhelmed by technology, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier and save time. However, Susan realized that technology can be expensive and not always worth the trouble. She started to let her household gadgets go as they stopped working. This made her question what "extra time" technology really gives us. Is it just time to buy more gadgets? Susan thinks we are being tricked by marketing experts.
When her word processor broke and made strange noises, she left it in the backyard. Now, she enjoys sewing by hand instead of using a noisy machine. She finds it relaxing and can take her sewing anywhere. While she appreciates some gadgets, like the washing machine, she found joy in losing others. For example, she returned her rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change made her family spend more time walking the dog, reading, and talking.
Sewing by hand has become a new hobby for Susan. Her old sewing machine is now a plant table, and she can't afford a new one, so she sews by hand. She used to think sewing by hand was hard work, but now she finds it soothing and satisfying. She can sew while listening to the radio or talking with family. It helps her slow down and enjoy life at her own pace. She also enjoys washing dishes by hand, which gives her time to daydream.
Susan now looks around her house and wonders if she really needs things like the freezer, microwave, or lawnmower. She even thinks about saving money by not using electric lights.

'The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from perfectly crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles Hurst seems like a man in a hurry. When I arrive at his workshop, located under a railway arch in East London, he greets me with a quick handshake and says, 'Well, fire away then!' It's not clear if he is really brusque or just shy. But looking around the workshop, it's obvious Hurst is busy. The space is full of half-made furniture and planks of wood in many natural colors. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has a great reputation. His order book is always full for months, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if you want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the person to go to. Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes beautifully crafted furniture with simple lines is rare. 'There are few real cabinet-makers now. People call themselves furniture-makers,' Hurst says. He is disappointed by some modern furniture. 'I am amazed by what some furniture-makers get away with, and saddened by what people will accept.' He dislikes poor-quality, mass-produced furniture and craftsmen who make second-rate pieces. Hurst's quest for perfection and his talent are keys to his success. He is confident about his ability. 'I have a huge natural ability,' he says. 'I have always been good at making things.' Hurst is self-taught. How did he learn? 'I asked the right questions and picked it all up,' he says. Most of his work comes from private clients. 'I used to do some commercial work for companies, but it was soul-destroying.' Some clients come back many times. 'You end up doing the whole of their house. That is very satisfying.' But he admits that relationships with clients are not always easy. 'The most annoying clients are those who don't know what they want, and then decide they do when it's too late ... my favorite clients are the exacting ones.' Hurst is pleased with himself but also praises others when deserved. 'There are people far better than me. I can admire other people. After all, I wasn't trained at Parnham' (a top furniture design college). He is critical of craftsmen who 'are trying to be artists and take a year to make one piece.' He also dislikes degree shows where students try to make fashion statements. 'That can be pretentious. A piece of furniture is not about making a statement. It has to be something that people really can use.' Hurst is confident and sometimes brusque, but not pretentious. As I leave, he shows humility. 'After all, I am only making furniture,' he says.'

'Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. It seems clear that sleep is very important. However, scientists still do not agree on exactly why we need to sleep so much. There are three main ideas. The most common idea is that sleep is mainly for our body's health. It says that we sleep to help our body stay healthy. While we sleep, our body fixes any damage from the day and gets ready for the next day. Another idea focuses on learning. This idea says that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. Without sleep, we would not be able to learn well. The third idea is about energy. It says we need sleep to recharge our energy, like recharging a battery, so we have enough energy for the next day.'

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is different from what is normal in society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Most people have their own little habits or interests. For example, some people love entering newspaper competitions, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to newspapers about many topics. Eccentricity is about being unique. Inside us, there is a struggle between wanting to be different and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains pushing against each other on the same track. One train is called individualism, and the other is conformity. For most people, conformity is stronger. We want to be accepted, loved, and feel like we belong. 
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find others like them. They form clubs and have meetings to share their interests. They look for people who understand them, as their family and friends might think they are odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, feels comforting. 
We all feel a pull between being ourselves and fitting in. Sometimes, we want to show we are different, like when someone at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new person says, "You must take me as you find me." 
Anyone can choose to be more individualistic. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, an American singer, said that when you follow your true feelings and don't give up, you might confuse people. But this is not eccentricity at first. When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention or a hostess makes shocking comments to be noticed, it is not eccentricity. If they keep doing these things until they can't go back to normal behavior, then they might be eccentric. 
The key to being eccentric is being natural. Eccentrics don't try to be different; they just are. They don't care about what others think. They do what they do because of who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are aware of the world and react to it. Some want to impress society, and some want to escape it, but they all think about society. Eccentrics, however, just live their lives without worrying about what others think.

**Natural Books**
We asked four naturalists to tell us about the wildlife book that influenced them the most.
**A Geoffrey Lean**
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in the field. None impressed me more than Barbara Ward, a small, frail woman who was central to environmental issues in post-war Europe. She turned her experiences into a powerful philosophy. As a young journalist, she helped me understand the field. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But "The Home of Man" is, to me, her most important book. It talks about the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It is a passionate call for what we now call 'sustainable human development'. I have read many books since, but none match it.
**B Linda Bennett**
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can imagine the sounds and smells of a herring gull colony. This book explains animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony changes from chaos to an organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with Eric Ennion, a talented wildlife artist, to create this book. Ennion's paintings, with simple lines and colors, show how one gull is aggressive and another is peaceful. This is the work of a true field naturalist.
**C Lee Durrell**
"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This book defined my love for the natural world. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. I was facing many challenges, but reading this book made my world brighter. It shows animals, people, joy, and beauty all connected. Many say humans are the worst because of the harm we cause, but I remember Gerald as a boy, seeing the world as a family. This is a concept we all need to understand.
**D Bruce Pearson**
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library after it was published in 1966. I was drawn to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and spent holidays learning to identify birds. They encouraged me to sketch birds to help with identification. But "The Shell Bird Book" offered more. It had chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and exciting images made me appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was as valid as a scientific one. Since art was my strong subject, I saw new opportunities for myself.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five top British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said:
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in a newspaper. The Book Marketing Council found that more people buy books because of reviews than for any other reason, like ads or word of mouth. Authors and publishers both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are usually calmer about bad reviews. They think that any mention, good or bad, can help sell books because readers want to decide for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinion of the book since they are often the first to read it.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and the press both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are still often ignored. Publishers need reviews because they help make a book and its author known. A good review by a trusted person can increase sales, especially if there are several reviews. Fame helps get books into readers' hands.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing. We publish books by authors who are not famous, so we rely on reviews since we rarely advertise. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because they are seen as honest opinions. Reviews can help sell books, but they need to work with other things like word of mouth and good marketing.
**Publisher D**  
In the US, a review in the New York Times can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops don't always pay attention to reviews. Sometimes it takes many years of good reviews for people to start reading a writer's work. Some poorly reviewed books sell very well, so it's unpredictable. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer's knowledge than the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want long, positive reviews. But do they sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it didn't sell because people felt they didn't need to buy the book after reading the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more, but now it's the surprise choice of reviewer or the quality of the review that can make people buy the book.

'WEATHERVANE MAKER The making of weathervanes is a very old skill, starting in early Egyptian times. Today, this craft is still alive in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham's designs are made especially for each customer. 'This way, I can make a unique and personal item,' he explains. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's job or hobbies.' This is very different from the traditional cockerel, which is the most common weathervane design. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick. He made it as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. 'I realized that I could make weathervanes in many different shapes,' he says. Graham decided to focus on a weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that job for 15 years. Then he and his wife, Liz, decided to change roles - she went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of the children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his new path. 'My old job was not artistic, but this is exciting and creative,' he says. 'I really enjoy designing.' Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He works with great detail and always gets the customer's approval for the design before cutting it by hand. Graham also keeps many traditional designs in stock because they are as popular as the custom ones. 'People like hand-made things,' Graham says. 'They like to have something a little different.' Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a small craft. 'I have found my place in the market.
