People love the uniqueness, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost lifelike,' he says. 'For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities by showing changes in the wind that bring changes in the weather,' he explains. 'Now, with more people moving to the countryside, they want to add a special touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine.' Graham is now very busy, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients around the world. Buyers from America and Denmark are especially interested. 'The price,' he explains, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His most recent request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.'

**Beginner Takes All**
Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it has made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about his inspiration and success.
The start of the year was tough for Nicholas Evans. He is a screenwriter, producer, and wants to be a director. Things went wrong when *Life and Limb*, a film he had been working on for months, suddenly failed. He was worried because he hadn't earned any money for two years, and this film was his only hope to pay the bank.
Instead of finding a job, Evans made a surprising decision. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months. The idea for the story came from a farrier he met on Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. Its owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. These men were called 'horse whisperers'. Evans was fascinated and started researching to write a screenplay. But after *Life and Limb* failed, he decided to write a book instead.
In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He felt alone and worried about his future. By August, he had written half of the book and showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent thought it was "fine" and said Evans might get $30,000 for it. Evans needed more money to pay his debts and support his family.
In October, the first 200 pages and a 12-page summary of the book were sent to seven UK publishers before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Soon, his agent called to say he had turned down an offer of $75,000. Evans was shocked. Within a week, the book was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel.
Evans was amazed. They hadn't even sent the book to New York or Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for it. His UK agent worked with an agent in the US, and they received an offer of $3 million for the film rights. Four big filmmakers called Evans to try to buy the rights to his unfinished novel.
Evans shared this story while we drank coffee at his home. He said he turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. He didn't want to ruin the fairy tale. Writing screenplays is tough, and he didn't want to work for people who had paid him so much. He wanted to stay involved but not too closely.
The success of his novel also brought new offers to make *Life and Limb*, but he wasn't sure he wanted to do it anymore. He thought it would be wise to write another novel.

'Young Masters Age is a challenge for Bobby Fischer as he tries to make a comeback. Chess is now more than ever a game for young people. After 20 years away from the game, Bobby Fischer is back and playing against his old rival Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game with a brilliant move, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in the best shape. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, and now it is more professional. Winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as important as their intelligence. The pressure is high: players must make a certain number of moves in a set time, or they lose the game. Games are longer now, and many are played without breaks. This gives an advantage to younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Of the world's top ten players, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Much of the game happens off the board. Players must prepare well before matches, especially because computers have changed chess a lot. A small computer can store one million chess games and help players study their opponents. In a recent match, both players had teams working to find weaknesses in each other's games. The opening moves are studied very carefully. Being well-prepared in the opening can decide the game. Today, there are more top players than ever before. Hundreds of grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Success needs both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours. During this time, players must stay focused. Losing concentration can lead to disaster. The chess clock adds to the tension. The end of the game can be a fast 'time scramble', where players have only seconds to make moves. They must move quickly and press their clocks with great skill. These moments are not for thinkers. The game becomes a battle of nerves and determination. At the top level, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Players must be ready to play again the next day. Most tournaments last 9-11 days, with games every day. World championship matches are even tougher. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to stop because both players were too tired. Karpov lost about 10kg in weight. Can Fischer beat these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his leaving the chess world in 1972 hard to understand. But it made him a legend. If he returned for money, he will earn a lot. Whatever happens in his match with Spassky, both will become much richer. But if Fischer came back to prove he is still the best, losing could be very sad for him.'

**Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A** Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as low as £30." The amazing thing about Nick is that before writing "Peaches," he had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because I know the problems it causes. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational environment. It was very exciting."
**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress since studying drama at Bristol University. He is now writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even at Bristol, he was performing in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comic group Funny Business, but his work with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably saw me copying him," Simon admits.
**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The reviews were very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "Now I can choose what I do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was always going to be successful. Encouraged by his mother, he went from lead roles at school to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," laughs Ciaran. "But then I decided to take it seriously because I was good at it and loved it." Now he is waiting for more praise, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about getting respect for good work."
**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released soon. "The record company talks about a big hit, but I have no idea. If two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. There were times when I was very depressed, and I've been in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."
**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards, 27, has won many prizes and awards. He is well known in the poetry world, where he has been touring and giving readings for six years. Now his first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but became unhappy with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with stuffing envelopes at a theatre, I decided to go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry being praised, moving to novels is brave. "There's a structure with my poetry, so there's less chance of making big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for bad words. My main goal is not to just produce work without caring about the quality."

A. Isabel, the main character in this funny novel, is an art student who is 31 years old. She loves historical romance stories and is looking for Mr. Right. Isabel thinks she looks good in jeans but doesn't wear them often because she doesn't want to be seen with the wrong people. She worries that her knobbly knees might stop her from finding love. However, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a fast-paced style like an old silent movie. B. This story is about the beginning and almost end of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of a smart child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town American setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. The story takes the reader back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of old-fashioned cars and radios. C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. Professor Richard Vaisey falls in love with a Russian poetess and talks about it with his wife's ex-husband. The poetess writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she wants his help for her brother, who is in prison. The author skillfully untangles these problems with humor and insight, making the story enjoyable and clever. D. Two pairs of best friends, two women and two men, meet in London in the 1960s and stay connected for 25 years. At the start of this long novel, one of them, an American businessman named James Hudson, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved (and one married) was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, with good writing that helps readers get to know the characters well. E. This story, written by a top American author, is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty for a mistake and decides to take care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, Ian is becoming an unusual bachelor surrounded by the mess of family life. The story explores many emotions and focuses on the sweet relationship Ian builds with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and touching book with a perfect mix of sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism: A Discussion**
**A.** Volunteer tourism is when people travel to other countries to help with projects like building homes or schools. However, volunteers often pay a lot of money to do this work. If this money was given directly to the local community, it might pay for more work than the volunteer can do. This is especially true for gap year students, who usually do not have special skills. Some studies question if these young people volunteer to help others or to improve their own careers. Still, these projects might help volunteers become more ethical and caring in their future lives.
**B.** Volunteering can help people understand each other better, solve conflicts, and participate in global issues. It can also create international friendships. This can be good for both volunteers and the communities they help. But if only rich people from wealthy countries volunteer, they might benefit more than the communities they visit. These volunteers might use the experience to advance their careers, while the communities gain little.
**C.** Sometimes, international volunteering can seem like charity from rich countries or a way for volunteers to improve themselves. But it can also be a way to share skills and knowledge between cultures. Volunteering can make people aware of global issues like poverty and injustice, and encourage them to fight these problems throughout their lives.
**D.** Volunteer tourism is popular because it seems like a simple way to help others. It avoids big government and business, focusing on personal acts of charity. However, it can also ignore the need for bigger changes in poor communities. While volunteering is a good act, calling it sustainable development can be misleading. It might distract from understanding and solving the real causes of global poverty.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**
Many of us listen to the radio when we wake up and need something to help us get out of bed. That's why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models.
The first model has a 'dual alarm function.' I thought it meant you could snooze and then wake up again, but it actually lets you set two different wake-up times, like one for weekdays and one for weekends. This model also has a cassette player, which is a good deal since it costs about the same as the second model. You can fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up without news. We liked the radio quality, but it's as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case.
The second model was the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges loved it, although the clock on his test model got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with grey numbers on a green background. The snooze bar is wide, so you can tap it with your eyes closed. It has a self-power back-up, so you don't have to reset it if the plug is pulled out. However, it was hard to set up, but once we learned, we felt 'cool' and sophisticated.
Tom Granger thought the third model, with its built-in lamp, was 'unbelievably tacky.' You have to pull the light out of its socket to use it, which made him question its quality. The clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00, so he had to reset it. The light only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges liked the lamp idea but found the radio hard to tune. The buzzer was loud and annoying, but this model is the third most popular on the market.
The fourth model is aimed at young people with its bright colors and strap. Tom Granger and I liked it because it stands out. It was the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. However, the alarm can be 10 minutes early or late, which Paul Bridges found 'completely useless.'
The last model is the simplest and cheapest. Tom Granger liked it because it was standard and took up little space. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found more intuitive. He admitted that button-tuning has improved radio quality, but we thought the tuning was crude. The buzzer worked well, getting me out of bed in just two beeps!

'Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines covering its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not native to America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are attacked, making their spines point outwards. This helps protect them from danger. The number of spines a hedgehog has can affect how well this works. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines because they need to be lighter. These hedgehogs might try to run away from danger first and only roll into a ball if they have to. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, usually under bushes or in a hole in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.'

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**
Being successful in sports is tough for everyone, but women often have to work even harder. Training and competitions take up a lot of time, so they have to make sacrifices. Despite challenges, these women are breaking records and overcoming prejudice. Here, we talk to some amazing British sportswomen who are achieving their dreams.
**A. Jill, 27, Skier**
"It's an amazing feeling to fly through the air and land perfectly, but it can be scary. Sometimes you don't feel well, or it's windy and hard to see, but you just keep going. It's difficult to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months a year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice. There are six men and three women in the British team. We all compete on the same courses and get treated the same - it's a young sport."
**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was amazing because I'd never cycled before! I'm well paid as a professional, and cycling has lots of potential for endorsements. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of how I look, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I focus on cycling now, rather than earning money. I train at least four hours every day on the bike, plus stretching exercises, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is a cyclist too, so he understands the time commitment."
**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**
"Rowing is hard for girls to start because very few girls' schools offer it. Most don't start until they're 19 or 20, which makes it harder to succeed internationally. Also, coaches usually stay for only a year or so, so there's no continuity, and the women's squad is often disorganized. But it's great fun, I love being fit, and there's a good social life."
**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**
"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the world—I didn't know how big it was then! Britain felt too small and safe. I was very determined and didn't like others controlling me. Now I am more tactful. Each walk is different. Walking across Australia was the most painful experience I've ever had. I walked 50 miles and 21 hours each day with only three hours of sleep, in high temperatures, and with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to, because my sponsorship money was running out after 95 days. Men often think women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is seen as a higher risk."
**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**
"Some men have big egos when driving—you see it on motorways. When I'm doing well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I reach a corner, men think 'I've got to beat her,' so I've had a lot of bumps! You have to be naturally competitive and aggressive. It's very hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have been racing since the 1920s and were always seen as unusual. It's great that more women are taking up racing every year. For me, the appeal of saloon car racing is aiming for perfection—always trying to complete a perfect lap."
**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**
"I get up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evening, I just cycle or run. Yes, I do fall asleep at my desk sometimes! There is a lot of nervous build-up before a race, and when you're racing, you really push yourself—you don't feel good if you don't. I've often asked myself why I do it. The answer is: a) I'm happier when I keep fit, b) I'm lazy at heart, and if I didn't make myself do this, I'd really be lazy, c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when an event is covered in the press, 90% of the article will explain the men's event, and 10% will say, 'Oh, by the way, so-and-so won the women's event.' The prize money isn't as good either, of course. But now we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission, so we're working on it."

**The Day I Drew Picasso**
Richard Cork remembers the day he met the famous artist Picasso. Richard was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van before starting university. He ran out of money and found a job painting boats in Cannes. One day, while eating at a restaurant in Cannes harbor, he saw Picasso, who was 78 years old, having lunch with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Picasso was known to be a private person, so Richard was surprised to see him.
Richard's friend encouraged him to ask Picasso for his autograph. Nervously, Richard approached Picasso and offered his sketchbook. Picasso kindly signed his name and added a drawing on the page. Richard was thrilled and started a conversation with Picasso, using an American woman at the table as an interpreter.
After showing the autograph to his friend, Richard was encouraged to go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Without asking for permission, Richard started drawing. Picasso noticed and made funny faces to make it difficult for Richard. Eventually, Picasso stopped and allowed Richard to draw him calmly. Richard observed Picasso's youthful appearance and intense eyes.
When Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the portrait. Although Richard was embarrassed, Picasso looked at it and then drew a quick sketch on the same page. Picasso's drawing was playful and different from Richard's careful work. Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso declined, saying Richard already had his signature.
Richard felt very lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention. This experience meant a lot to him.

**Shopping Tricks**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? We explain the tricks shops use to make you spend more money.
**A. Freshness Image**
Supermarkets know that customers like fresh products. They often put fruits and vegetables at the store entrance or have a display of house plants to show freshness. They might also have a bakery inside that spreads the smell of fresh bread. The store's colors, like green, can also make things look fresh. Most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is different from this fresh image.
**B. Smart Display**
Where products are placed in a store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas are most popular with shoppers. They put high-profit items or fast-selling products in these spots. Shelves at eye level are popular because they sell better. Special offer bins attract people who love bargains. Stores also use 'complementation' by placing related items together, like salad dressings near salads.
**C. Spreading Essentials**
Supermarkets put basic items like bread, tea, and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by other tempting products. Chain stores do the same with popular items, placing them far from the entrance. They know loyal customers will look for these items and might buy other things along the way.
**D. Less is More**
Chain stores have changed how they display products. The Next chain, for example, moved away from the 'pile them high, sell them cheap' method. Their stores look like boutiques, showing fewer items to make them seem special. Even though their clothes are mass-produced, the store design makes them look exclusive.
**E. Total Temptation**
Food shoppers care more about the total bill than individual prices. Supermarkets mix low-profit staples with high-profit items. Not everything in a supermarket is cheap. They might sell some items at a loss to attract customers, known as 'loss leaders'. They also buy in bulk to get discounts from manufacturers.
**F. Price Tags Matter**
In chain stores, shoppers buy fewer items and notice prices more. Pricing something at $14.99 instead of $15 is still effective. It also helps reduce theft because staff must ring up the sale to give change.
**G. Effective Lighting**
Both supermarkets and chain stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores aim for natural light so clothes look the same as they would outside. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to make fresh food look better.
**H. Walking Paths**
Some chain stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the path through the store, and another marks sales areas. This is called the 'Yellow Brick Road'. It doesn't always work, as some shoppers stick to the path. Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths, leading to more inviting carpeted sales areas.
**I. In-Store Ads**
When you enter a supermarket, you see big photos of delicious food. In the U.S., some supermarkets use 'video trolleys' with screens that show ads as you shop. Sensors trigger ads for products near you, like ready-made meals. These trolleys target impulse buyers and can increase sales by about 30%.

'Sea, Ice & Rock Mountaineer Chris Bonnington (58) is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and written many books, like Quest for Adventure and Everest the Hard Way. Robin Knox-Johnston (53) started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone, in his yacht Sunhaili. He broke the transatlantic record, taking 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard. The two teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about the trip in their new book: Sea, Ice and Rock. In 1979, I was working on Quest for Adventure, a study of post-war adventure. I called Robin to ask for an interview, and he invited me to join him for a sail. I could show him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first time on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat, and we paddled to the shore to practice climbing. The route was quite difficult, and I was impressed by how steady Robin was in tricky conditions. He moved quietly along. After a bit, we reached a huge drop. I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn't, so I showed him. When I finished, Robin politely asked if he could go down the way he climbed down ropes on his boat. He was used to using his arms, but I wanted him to use his legs. I wasn't too happy about it, but he lowered himself down safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I became good friends. His idea to combine our skills on a trip to Greenland was just a bigger version of our Skye trip. Robin impressed me as a leader. Usually, the skipper makes all the decisions, but Robin asked everyone first. Most of the time, nobody dared to advise him, but it was nice to feel part of the decision-making process. To be honest, I found the sailing difficult and boring. The moments of crisis on the way back were easy to handle: the adrenaline pumps, and you get all worked up. The hard part was spending day after day in the middle of the sea. I love the land and am not really a do-it-yourself person. Robin, on the other hand, is a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or mending the toilet. I knew Robin didn't really need me. To be honest, I felt a bit useless at times; I found that hard. The crew was also packed very close together: six people on a 32ft yacht, designed to sleep four. At least on a mountain expedition, you can get away from each other. When we reached Greenland, and it was my turn to 'lead' the expedition, I found it hard to be responsible for Robin's life. There were many times climbing together when if Robin had fallen, he could have pulled me off with him. I had to watch for that constantly. I underestimated how difficult the Cathedral -- Greenland's highest mountain - would be. Robin isn't a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. The first time we tried to reach the top, we were on the go for 24 hours. On the way down, we were falling asleep on 50-degree slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin went through a lot, but he totally trusted me. He just followed. When it got too difficult, and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted it. I also knew that Robin was worried about the boat: whether we'd be able to get it through the ice, whether it was in one piece. Yet he was all in favor of us trying to climb the mountain again. The only time there was a near-crisis in our relationship was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns to be on watch. I was supposed to get up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me. He felt he could do it himself. The previous night I'd almost fallen asleep. I felt that he didn't trust me - I felt insecure, and I said so. Robin immediately reassured me that I'd jumped to the wrong conclusion. While we enjoyed the Skye trip, we didn't really know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. I found that underneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind-hearted, sensitive person.'

**A History of the Apple**
Apples have been with us for a very long time, in many different colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late 20th century, we risk losing this heritage.
**Prehistoric Wild Apples (8,000 BC)**
People have been eating apples since prehistoric times. In ancient Britain, they spat out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people stored apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and wrinkled, known as 'windings' in Ancient Britain. They were very different from the apples we know today.
**Norman Knowledge (1000 AD)**
The French learned fruit-growing skills from the Romans, which they developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. The dessert apple, Decio, was introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, most Roman apples did not suit the British climate, so Norman varieties became more popular. British monks continued to develop new apples, and many Western apples come from these varieties.
**Medieval Favorites (1200)**
In the 13th century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, recorded in 1204, was the main dessert apple until the 18th century. Its cooking partner was the Costard, sold in Oxford markets from 1296 to the 17th century, giving us the word 'costermonger' for someone who sells fruit and vegetables on the street. Apple production declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses. More apples were imported until the 16th century when Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apple growing. Harris brought back many apple grafts, including the famous Pippins, and created the first modern orchard in Kent.
**Settler Treasure (1750)**
By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed', planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. He was seen as a medicine man by the Indians and became a folk hero.
**Modern Delicious (1850)**
Around this time in Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree growing. He named the apple 'Hawkey'. At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed 'Delicious, delicious!'. In 1895, it was introduced as 'Delicious' and became one of the most popular apples worldwide.
**Granny Smith (1850)**
Another famous apple was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. Known as 'Granny Smith', she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit in 1868. She transplanted it and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. She said, 'It's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish', referring to both the fruit and her convict origins.
**Uniformity (1950)**
Apples are now grown worldwide, from India to Africa. Most are grown commercially and come from just a few varieties, chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, not for taste. This uniformity is reducing the variety of apples. While UK gardeners have kept many old varieties alive, the US has lost most of its apples from 100 years ago. Consumers are now asking for more variety. We must protect natural diversity in apples and other foods for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**
Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel. We offer trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. Our focus is on new and unusual places with interesting plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.
**Small Groups**
Our groups are small, with about 16 people. They are informal and led by experts. This gives you a chance to learn more about the places we visit. You will get closer to the local culture and people, making your trip more exciting.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport, often on the same trip. This includes buses, trains, expedition vehicles, minibuses, boats, canoes, rafts, camels, light planes, and walking. Each trip matches the local area.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people who like new experiences. They come mainly from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are aged 25-55. About half are couples, and the rest are individuals traveling alone.
**Activities and Interests**
Each trip is unique, so we have 8 categories to describe them. Each category highlights a special part of the tour. Many factors make our trips successful, like unique places, unusual encounters, and personal involvement.
**Cultural/Adventure**
Most trips have a strong cultural focus. Some tours focus on local cultures and historic sites. Destinations include Egypt, Jordan, Turkey, India, China, Peru, and more. Short walks of 2-4 hours to off-the-beaten-path sites are often included.
**Wildlife and Natural History**
Our wildlife safaris visit famous game parks and offer close encounters with animals. In Africa, you can step out of your safari vehicle and explore. You might track gorillas in Zaire or canoe on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel stays. In Asia and South America, we often stay in hotels or lodges.
**Ethnic Encounters**
A highlight of our trips is meeting ethnic or tribal peoples, like the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico. We travel in small groups to minimize cultural and environmental impact.
**Easy/Moderate Hiking**
Many trips include easy walks through the countryside, staying in rented or hotel accommodation. You might hike from village to village, staying overnight in private houses or huts. Your main luggage is transported separately.
**Major Treks**
We offer a few major treks for strong walkers. These involve high altitudes and may include staying with locals or camping. We use support vehicles or porters, so you don't carry heavy gear.
**Wilderness Experience**
Explore remote wilderness areas like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These adventures offer a chance to see exotic places few people visit.
**Sailtreks/Seatreks**
These relaxing holidays use local boats. We sail through places like Egypt and Turkey, exploring islands and unique wildlife habitats.
**Raft and River Journeys**
River trips can last from a few hours to several days. They range from easy paddling to exciting whitewater rafting. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. Our river trips offer a unique view of the local environment.

'Richard Nerurkar, a top British 10,000-metre runner, visits the Kenyan high-altitude training camp. This camp is near Mount Kenya, which is the highest mountain in Kenya. For three years, Richard trained in Kenya's Central Highlands during winter, but he never trained with Kenyan runners. On his fourth trip, he changed this. He competed in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. This camp is where Kenya's best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. Richard was invited by the national team coach after he finished fifth in a World Championship 10,000 meters race. Training at high altitude helps runners because it increases red blood cells, which carry oxygen. This is one reason why Kenyan runners are successful. Richard's first race in Africa was in Nairobi. It was the first international cross-country race in Africa. He finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan. He realized that Kenyan success is not just because of altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple approach to running. They run with ease, eat simple food, and enjoy competing. Richard learned more about their training during his stay at the camp. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. It is basic, with few comforts. Athletes live with students and share rooms. Their day includes three workouts: an easy morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the afternoon. They run about 40 kilometers a day, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometers. Life at the camp is simple. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are ugali, stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they bathe in streams from Mount Kenya. Richard left the camp with a new appreciation for Kenyan success. It is not just genetics or altitude. The simple lifestyle, hard training, and passion for success are key to Kenya's success in distance running.'

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**
Advertising is having a tough time. It's not just because of the recession. Advertising started to drop in 1989, even before the recession hit hard. The problems with advertising are deeper and happening all over the world. Advertising hasn't kept up with economic changes. Advertisers think about big markets and big media, but as more brands and media have appeared, target markets have become smaller. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller audiences, but they often don't. This is where advertising has gone wrong.
Think about your shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items. Many of these won't be advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 products in the store. Over a year, you probably buy only a few hundred brands. For things like cars, you might buy one every three years, and it might be provided by your employer. You don't buy many clothes either, and most aren't advertised brands. Even with things like candy, medicine, and services, you probably don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.
Compare that to the 32,500 branded goods and services advertised. Let's focus on the 9,500 brands that spend more on advertising. The average person buys 400 of those 9,500, and not all because of advertising. That's about 4 percent. So, you could say 96 percent of advertising is wasted, but nobody knows which part. When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about 1 in 16 (6 percent), so the other 15 (94 percent) seem wasted.
You might think you're not affected by advertising, but almost everyone thinks that. The truth is, nobody buys most of the brands they see advertised. Waste is part of using media for advertising. Not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest, so waste can't be avoided. But advertising can still be cost-effective. It reaches many people to find the few who will respond, because advertisers can't know in advance who will be interested.
Media advertising works because it's a cheap way to communicate with many people. However, all waste is unpleasant. With smart targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who will respond, but they can never know exactly who will. Even the best direct mail doesn't get a 100 percent response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every client. This can't happen with media. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they wouldn't need media. They could contact people directly.
Any advertiser who gains one million new customers (2 percent of the adult population) is doing well. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million extra customers. Any advertising campaign that wins over 2 percent of the population would be very successful. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message more precisely than ever before.

'Solar Survivor Charles Clover visits Britain's most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire has some surprises. One is Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral with 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen. Another is Britain's greenest house, the 'autonomous house', designed by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into garden compost, and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is 300 yards from the Minster. It matches the town's old buildings and was approved by planners even though it is in a conservation area. The house is super-insulated, with special windows, so you don't hear any noise inside. Inside, you must take off your shoes, and it feels very quiet. On a sunny day, the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Vale opens ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow because the house is very draught-proof. Even the cats have their own air-locked door. The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, cared about the environment long before it became a big issue. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s, The Autonomous House. They designed a building that emits no carbon dioxide and decided to do without mains water. They use composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and copper gutters to protect drinking water, which they filter before use. Water from washing goes into the garden. They don't have a dishwasher because they don't want to use strong detergents. 'We wanted to show that it was possible to design a house that is less harmful to the environment, without living in the dark,' says Robert. The house's only medieval aspect is its look: the hall, with the hearth and staircase, is the full height of the building. The Vales pay no water bills. Last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p, which is what other four-bedroom houses use on top of heating. Soon it will use even less when solar panels and equipment are installed in the garden. The house will use electricity from the mains for cooking and appliances but will generate extra electricity. There will even be enough to charge an electric car. The only heating is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which the Vales say they use only in the very coldest winter. Is it warm in winter? One night in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The room temperature was 18C, which is less than usual for living areas, but comfortable because there are no draughts and no heat loss. An Edwardian lady in the early 1900s was comfortable at 12.5C because of her clothing. People in old houses should live like they did then, he suggests. But this idea might not catch on. The house is low-tech, so there is little to go wrong. Most materials were from a builder's merchant and installed by local craftsmen. This made the house cheap to build, costing the same per square metre as low-cost housing for rent. Commercial building companies are not interested in this idea.'

'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a logical man, like a scientist. But in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies in a garden, he believed they were real proof that fairies existed. He published the photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were amazing supernatural things. It wasn't until 1939 that the two women who took the photos admitted they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are very beautiful. But the simple trick shows that a basic idea about photography, that the camera cannot lie, is not true. The camera can lie, and it always could. Today, we use computer software to change our digital photos, and it is not true that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the start, when cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

'Blacksmiths Throughout history, iron has been very important to people, and those who work with it, called blacksmiths, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The flowing metal designs of French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were also made by talented blacksmiths. However, by the late 1960s in Britain, blacksmiths were almost gone because heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern buildings rarely used elegant wrought-iron designs. In the past 10 years, there has been a revival due to more interest in decorative architecture and creative interior design. Still, much of the work seems old-fashioned, with gates and balconies often described as 'classical' or 'Victorian-style'. In trendy design stores, you often see rusty candlesticks with decorations. Fortunately, there are new options, and several events in the coming weeks aim to promote blacksmithing. The first event is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA) at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, BABA's secretary, says, 'We might be starting a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently.' Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld it easily. 'In short,' says Dawson, 'these artists now have a material that lets them express themselves.' About 250 pieces are in the show, from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go much higher. Most of the money will go to the makers, but some will support the promotion of good ironwork, says Dawson. His own works include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. 'My style comes from letting steel bend and flow when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space,' he says. Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are easy to shape when cold, iron and steel are tougher. Susan May, a jeweler, says, 'It's magical because it's very soft when hot, but becomes hard and unmovable when it cools.' Ann Catrin Evans' steel door-knockers and handles look like they belong in horror films. One design is like a ball and chain, another like a Celtic cross. 'I love that steel is cold and hard,' she says. 'And it feels like it will last forever.' No other metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater feeling of security. Iron will likely be used decoratively for many years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.'

'THE DAY I STOPPED SMOKING I thought everyone would be happy, but one of my colleagues was very angry. 'What do you mean?' she shouted. 'If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?' I couldn't really explain how one afternoon I was a heavy smoker, and four hours later I wasn't. It even surprised me. The stop-smoking session was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened exactly two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to stop, and I didn't really want to. I didn't like the pressure from people who wanted me to quit smoking - and I still don't. Also, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn't cough or feel sick and seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives. On that normal Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about other people trying to quit. 'I won't try to stop myself, it wouldn't be fair,' I said. 'Since I'm here to write, not to quit, it wouldn't be right to expect your method to work on me.' I thought I was being reasonable. After all, I really enjoyed smoking. It made me happy. I thought the counsellor looked at me knowingly. We were allowed to smoke as much as we wanted, and most of the afternoon was in a room so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn't want to - and neither did the others. I guess the stop-smoking messages made sense. Just as smoking had become a challenge because people were against it, the idea of stopping started to feel interesting. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a secret feeling just for me. Could I also conquer the world? In many ways, it was easy. The physical craving for nicotine, like hunger, went away after a minute or two, and I only felt it for four or five days. The one thing I thought would be hardest without cigarettes - my work - wasn't a problem at all. I really believed I couldn't work to deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, spending time at home on weekend mornings was the hardest - and it still is. I think smoking was a way to avoid boredom; having a cigarette was something to do. Yes, I do miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each 'new' experience as a non-smoker has to be faced - eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, a theatre break. All are key moments when I used to smoke.'

Dorothy Hodgkin: A Forgotten Scientist
Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but not many people in Britain know her name. Georgina Ferry, who is writing Hodgkin's biography, has noticed this. When she tells people about her work, only a few recognize Hodgkin's name.
Why should people know about Dorothy Hodgkin? Winning a Nobel Prize is a big achievement. If she had won in literature, she would be famous. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like the progress of women's education and the spread of science around the world.
When Ferry started her research, she read other scientific biographies. A friend suggested a book about Linus Pauling, a famous chemist and friend of Hodgkin. But she couldn't find it in her local bookshop. This surprised her because Pauling was a very important chemist and won Nobel Prizes in chemistry and peace.
Some people think scientific biographies are boring. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, said that scientists' lives are not interesting to read about. This view makes publishers and booksellers less interested in these stories. There is a belief that science and the arts are very different, which affects how scientists are seen in biographies.
However, scientists can have interesting lives, just like artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists avoid media attention because they don't want to seem self-promoting. But this can give a wrong idea about science and discourage young people from becoming scientists.
Things are changing. Scientists now appear more in public. For example, Richard Dawkins presents TV quiz prizes, and Steve Jones advertises cars. These activities help people see scientists as real people.
The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be serious and not very exciting. But books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?" show scientists as real people with interesting lives. Now, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein are shown with their personal flaws.
Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her work. She solved the structures of penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin, which won her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964. She also had three children and a husband who was often away. Her personal life may not seem important to her work, but it shows how she balanced different parts of her life.
Hodgkin's life is interesting not just for her science but also for how she lived. Scientific inquiry was her passion, and understanding this passion is a challenge for biographers. Many readers don't have the scientific background to understand complex ideas easily. But learning science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just takes effort.
It's unfortunate that many educated people don't know about scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they are part of our rich heritage.

Margaret and her special skill
Margaret Wilkins has a special skill called a 'sixth sense'. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells dry up. Margaret and her husband have a business that drills wells. They use machines like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. But to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.
Dowsing is the skill of finding water, minerals, or lost things underground. Some people think it is a 'sixth sense'. There are many ideas about how it works. Some say it is because of magnetism, while others think it is spiritual. One idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Dowsers might be able to feel these vibrations. Some say they can 'sense' water, while others say they can smell it.
The Wilkins have been very busy during recent droughts. At one point, they had a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of Margaret's customers are farmers with dry wells. She says, 'We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time.' Other customers have remote cottages or barns, now used as holiday homes, where it is too expensive to run water pipes. Some customers are golf-course developers who need water for their clubhouses.
Margaret tries to find water 50 to 70 meters deep. 'You can't drill a well where farm waste might get into the water. The water we find is in cracks in hard rock, and if we bring it straight up, it should be clean. But in Cornwall, you have to watch out for iron.' They also need electricity to run the pump, so the well should be near power supplies.
Margaret starts looking for water with a map and a pendulum on large areas like golf courses. 'I hold the pendulum still and move it over the map. It swings when there is water below.' After finding likely areas on the map, she walks over the fields with her hazel stick. 'When I'm above water, I feel strange and use the stick to find the exact spot to drill.' She holds the stick with both hands and pulls it slightly. 'When water is below, the stick rises. It's important to drill exactly where the stick shows. If you drill in the wrong place, you can miss the water. My husband checks the same area, and we usually agree on where to drill. If we don't agree, we keep looking.'
Margaret is not alone in using this old skill in the west of England. Many people are interested in this mysterious ability. Margaret calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This might explain why she finds water so well. Without this 'sixth sense', how could her family run their well-drilling business successfully year after year?

**We changed lives for a day!**
Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to do something different for a change. We arranged this for four people - read about their experiences.
**Amanda's Story**
Amanda, a 23-year-old mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant.
I had never been in a place like it before. It was so dark and noisy, with many people and a great atmosphere. It was very different from my hometown, and I wasn't sure I would manage! Being a mother is a busy job, but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks fell off the tray and crashed to the floor. I was so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first!
By opening time at 11:30 am, a queue had already formed outside, and I felt nervous. I was worried about remembering all the orders, but everything was automated. After a couple of hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn't get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say 'Pardon?', which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was exhausted and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. I couldn't believe it when one of the waitresses said it had been a 'quiet' day! I never realized how tiring waitressing would be. I've always thought it was a job for shy people, but you need to be friendly and able to handle lots of customers. I'm quite shy, and I don't think I could cope on a busy Saturday night. I wasn't impressed with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich Americans didn't tip me! I was glad to get back to my children. It seems easy after waitressing!
**Cindy's Story**
Cindy was a bit nervous about being a 'mum' for the day, but she was looking forward to it too. She had been warned the girls were cheeky, but she thought she could handle it. Little did she know!
As Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I'd have three hours of peace. Wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me to make the beds, clean the house, and do the washing. At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble started. They turned the sofa into a trampoline and screamed loudly! I thought they'd get tired soon. Wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they beat me! After much persuasion, I got them into bed by 8 pm, but then the fun started! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I knew it was just a trick to come downstairs and watch TV, but it was exhausting to spend all evening negotiating with them. I never realized how tiring it could be looking after two small children. You don't get a second to think about yourself, and the responsibility is overwhelming. Even so, I really enjoyed the day.
**Rosemary's Story**
Rosemary, 42, runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary, 30, a teacher at a primary school.
On the farm, I have to get up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a luxury! But I worried about how to look. I couldn't turn up in overalls and boots, could I? Looking at about 400 pupils at assembly, I hoped I blended in and didn't stand out as being from the farm. After that, it was time for a maths class. The children worked in small groups, using workcards graded by difficulty - different from when I was at school! Then I helped with a nature project - identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, I was exhausted and looking forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There's so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (bliss!) and then a French lesson. This was fun because the children wanted to practice on me, which showed my rusty French. Finally, we went to the school hall for Physical Education. I was drained, but the children had endless energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class. Teachers may get more holidays, but I think I'll stick to farming!
**Hilary's Story**
Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary's 280-acre farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 ewes. She also makes ice-cream, yoghurt, and cream, which is sold in shops and restaurants.
I spent most of the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk, squeezing ice-cream into cartons, and sticking on labels. It was hard not to taste the goodies! At lunchtime, it was time to check the sheep. I drove to a field and picked up a ewe that had fallen over. If sheep are left for more than 12 hours once they fall, they could die, so they have to be checked every day. What a nightmare it must be in winter! After feeding the calves, I started the milking. It took two-and-a-half hours. And Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, seven days a week, 365 days a year! I found it quite lonely. I missed the children - animals don't talk back! The worst part is not being able to get away from work. The cows always have to be milked, so it's hard to plan time off. Rosemary will only get about three days' holiday this year. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is different. The income is irregular, and I'd hate to depend on the weather.

'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many musicians come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who didn't play music, grew up in a country area of southern Sweden. At 30, he is now one of the world's top trumpet players. His records include not only concertos by old composers but also new works. When you meet him, he looks young and friendly, just like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a TV show talked about his work and growth, filmed in both London and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his career started with a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give him a real trumpet, not a toy. The gift was a success, and Hakan never stopped playing. His mother found a teacher for him, the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson. Nilsson saw Hakan's talent right away. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a teacher who loved the trumpet and was always looking for new ways to play it. Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is not a perfect instrument, and each one has its flaws. He believes in understanding these flaws and working with them. From the start, he had a special sound, which he developed as a child. Unlike John Wallace, a famous British trumpet player who started in brass bands, Hardenberger always saw himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre and collected all his records. His parents supported his dream to become a professional trumpet player. At 15, he needed to decide where to study. America was too far and dangerous, so he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud advised against joining an orchestra, comparing it to gardening. Hardenberger knew he played better than others his age, but it was during a competition in Paris at 17 that he realized he had a special gift for connecting with people. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. He learned the pieces for the first round and advanced to the second. He knew most of the pieces in that round too, but in the final, he faced a difficult concerto. He didn't win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and realized people listened to him even if he thought he didn't play well. Hardenberger is realistic about his work and career. He doesn't try to explain his gift for communication, as he believes it might ruin it. He thinks the power of music is in its ability to move people.'

**New In Paperback**
A. The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It is a special tale about human power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and customs. The book is known for its humor and the author's unique way of seeing things. It is a challenging but rewarding read.
B. Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not meet Sheila, a working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and her grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about it. Leo, who was a good student, does not explain why he did it. Joe recovers physically but becomes quiet. Harriet is worried about her son, and taking care of him becomes her main focus. Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unusual friendship. The author is good at showing how people react to big changes in their lives and how mothers feel they can never do enough.
C. This book was shortlisted for the Booker prize. It tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long history. The story is set against important moments in Scottish history, imagined by the young main character, Thorfinn Ragnarson. He disappears at one point but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate his ancestors' simple lives.
D. After a successful book, the author has written a sequel with the same gentle irony and observations of family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies with her friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora is still charming and kind, and Rosie helps her manage her relationships. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is taking over. The author is good at showing the sadness beneath ordinary life and how events can be random.
E. Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to describe their personal journeys of self-discovery. Each person returns home with a new spirit, changed by their time on the sea. The author uses surprising images to show themes of memory and awareness, which are both strange and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their different jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and their usual workday.
**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  
**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and start work by 8 am. I begin operating at 8:30 am. I operate all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most head operations take three hours, but some can last all day. I've worked ten hours straight without eating or using the bathroom. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. I don't feel stressed while operating, but I do worry about the next day's plans. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it works, it's amazing and makes up for the times it doesn't. From 10 am to 1 pm, I have an out-patients' clinic where I explain the operations. I enjoy talking to patients, but time pressure can make it hard to comfort them if they are upset. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I'm on call and always carry my pager. On holidays, I worry for the first three days about my patients, and I dream about operating. I find it hard to relax."
**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  
**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I get up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, take the train, and arrive at work by 9:15 am. On Monday at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our work, any problems, or if anyone needs help. We work in teams. My team has three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. The work is mostly production, with only ten to fifteen percent design. I get a brief from the client, and then spend three or four weeks designing and developing the project. After presenting my ideas to the client and getting approval, we work on estimates and budgets. I start hiring photographers and illustrators, and I work with printers to meet job needs on time. I spend a lot of time managing people and need to communicate well with them. When their work is done, I assemble everything and send it to the printers. Managing several jobs at once can be very stressful. Deadlines are always near, and no day is the same. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, and we try to go to the pub. Otherwise, I have sandwiches and work through. It's great when the client likes the designs, but disappointing if the job is rejected. I get home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often later. I find it hard to relax when I get back, especially if I'm busy."
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  
**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually get up at 7 am, but two or three times a week, I meet a long-haul flight and get up between 4:30 am and 5 am. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Because driving is a sitting job, I have to watch my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and just snacks during the day. People often ask me to recommend places, so I need to know my way around. Many jobs are pre-booked, so I can check routes beforehand. Not everyone is polite. Some passengers are rude, but most are well-behaved, and I have a good relationship with regular clients. Sometimes I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. The press has tried to make me talk about clients, but I won't. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I have to be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  
**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I get up at 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I mostly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial jobs, but mostly private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. At 11 am, we get hungry and go to a cafe for breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. The business office is at home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants their garden landscaped, I arrange a consultation in the evening. We use old materials and unusual plants to make gardens look old. Sometimes people have specific ideas that aren't great. It's satisfying to see a garden finished and blooming. It's hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone. I never have trouble sleeping because the work is physical, and I'm always tired. I'm not very strong, but I'm fit. It's a tough job, but it lets your imagination run wild."
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  
**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the site by 8:30 am. I'm the assistant resident engineer, looking after the building of bridges and a wall to prevent cars from driving into a quarry. I check that contractors follow the schedule and safety rules with minimal environmental impact. I help coordinate site professionals and solve problems. Contractors start at 6 am, so my first task is to find out from the clerk of works what's happened since I left. The rest of the day depends on what he tells me. There's usually paperwork or design questions to answer. Lunch is usually for half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I eat as I go. When contractors are on break, it's easier to check the site. Checking their work can cause conflict, so we need an open relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but if something important comes up, I act immediately. I usually leave the site at about 6 pm and I'm on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7.30 am. I manage customer programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in Europe. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and answering emails. I handle all advertising for the membership program in Europe, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan strategies. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6.30 pm and 7.00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**
I start work at 10.00 am and go through the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters, and invoices. The phone starts ringing at 10.30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day about campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be constructive. I know if the sound fits our record label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs and producers. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing. I also manage budgets. I leave work at 7.00 pm and often go to gigs, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. I might visit an artist in the studio after a gig. I usually get home by 1.00 am and listen to a record to relax.
**C. Sales Director**
I get up at 8.00 am and arrive at work by 9.30 am. I check the diary for client visits and enjoy showing people around the showrooms. We sell antiques from £1,000 to £6,000 and buy from various sources. Many items need restoration, so I work with restorers and repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette to stay updated and visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts monthly and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5.30 pm and take about an hour to relax.
**D. Air Traffic Controller**
I work in shifts and leave home at 6.00 am for early shifts. At 7.00 am, I take over one of the four control positions in the tower. We rotate stations, working for about an hour and a half, then taking a break. We control aircraft movements as a team. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing time to read up on new requirements. It's important to be alert, so I take sick leave if needed. The job is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and maybe a general manager.
**E. Shop Manager**
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8.00 am. I start by setting up the electronic sales system. I ensure someone watches the till and coordinate breaks. I help customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be annoying if they expect too much. Between 2.00 pm and 4.00 pm, publishers' reps visit, and I discuss new titles. I decide how many copies to order. If we feature a new title, I ensure timely delivery. The early shift ends at 5.45 pm. I work late shifts twice a week, closing the shop and going home.
**F. Financial Analyst**
I listen to the news at 7.00 am, then take a taxi to work by 8.45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about my region. I assess financial risks for companies abroad, warning clients of potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information guide. From 9.15 am to 9.30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. My first preview is due by 10.00 am, and the second by 11.00 am, so I work quickly. I type stories, send them to my editor, and make changes before they go online. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events. I leave work around 6.00 pm, but it's hard to relax, and I'm often awake until 1.00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**
A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**
A good leader inspires others and brings change. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote "Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace," says leadership is about making things happen with people who are as excited as you are. Enthusiasm is important, and a good leader should speak clearly and confidently. Dixon says, "It's having the confidence to say 'I believe' instead of 'I think.'"
B. **Discovering Leadership Potential**
John van Maurik, a director of a Leadership in Management course, believes many people have more leadership potential than they know. Becoming a leader means recognizing and developing these hidden talents. We are all born with some leadership ability, but we need the right situations to grow. While it's easy to see leadership in famous people like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplace. Yet, leadership is very important for good management.
C. **Comparing Leaders and Managers**
Think about the best and worst boss you've had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they do it? The best leader motivated and supported you. The worst made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first was a good leader; the second was a poor manager.
D. **Leaders vs. Managers**
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like working within set rules. Leaders create new paths. Michael Shea, author of "Leadership Rules," says a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a struggling organization, whether it's a company, a sports team, or a country.
