Years ago, they visited the factory to see how gloves were made. Marie's favorite part was the laying-off table, where men shaped and pressed gloves over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table. Marie called them 'pancake hands' because they looked flat.
Rita asked Seymour, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' He replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She took notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained, 'They come to the tannery. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they make it ready for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' Rita said, 'Not yet.' Seymour offered to arrange a visit for her, saying, 'They're primitive places. The technology has improved, but it's not much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. Tanning is said to be the oldest industry, with remains found from six thousand years ago in Turkey. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. My father is the leather expert; you should talk to him. He can talk about gloves for two days. Glovemen love the trade. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' Rita replied, 'I can't say I have. I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' Seymour laughed. Rita made him laugh. She was eager to learn, like his daughter Marie, who was taller and fairer than Rita but had the same intelligence and curiosity. Seymour decided, 'I'll show you the whole process. We'll make you a pair of gloves, and you'll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

'Is it a tough job? Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as wonderful as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from the taxi taking her to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss wants her to be in Los Angeles instead. When you're a personal assistant to a pop star, you have to travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. There's just one small problem - she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour trip to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help calm me down,' she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so closed in with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring paperwork - organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for the job. She met the manager of a pop group by chance, which led to a job offer. She took a secretarial course at night school at the same time. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has been an accountant and a golf caddy, a person who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he preferred being a caddy. Well, you would too if golf was your passion. There were some downsides, though. A small flat fee is given, plus a percentage of the winnings. The average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, and much of that goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for the golfer, Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were recently recognized by European Tour Productions when they made him a statistical data administrator. From cards brought in by the caddies, he compiles and analyzes the statistics of each day's play. The results are wanted by TV commentators, golfing magazines, and the golfers themselves. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to try the food in the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge very high prices? 'For those who can afford it, it's up to them,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a meal I'll remember for the rest of my life than buy a microwave.' It was his talent as a cook that led to the offer of a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, who was then a creative director of an advertising agency, it was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper called to offer a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession.' He still does all the cooking at home and tries to keep his waistline under control by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. 'Before that, I always loved words and enjoyed using them, but my writing was mainly poetry. Then I had this idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a kind of role reversal story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That is what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not up with the dawn, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend another couple of hours typing out the morning's scribbling - all of which I do with one finger on an old portable typewriter rather than on one of those awful laptops. I get between 50 and a hundred letters a week, and that is the part about being a writer that I enjoy the most. I do try to answer them all, but nowadays I have some secretarial help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were made into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust. These golden piles covered the yard all the way to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, all the boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed on the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he said, trying to get them to follow him. Laughing, he watched them from the roof, looking scared, but one by one, they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. Then one boy said, "Let's go up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they all went up and started jumping off again until only Michael was left. The others were below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to jump and join them, but he stayed on the roof, nervous, with a silly smile, wondering why it seemed so far down this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried counting to ten and then jumping, but it didn't work. He tried taking a deep breath and closing his eyes. After a while, the boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted. When he didn't move, they started to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for almost an hour while the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set beyond the lake. His clothes were wet from sweating nervously. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump, then got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to come home on time. If you won't come home, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled anger, but Michael, with his dark, sad face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the boys laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**
Are you unhappy with your job but unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change their job are turning to careers advisers. You will need to write a short history of yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a summary with career suggestions and possible retraining options.
I decided to try Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school exams. I was with about ten people, answering questions quickly. I had to remember it wasn't about passing or failing. The tests included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the tests, I talked with an adviser who gave me a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, though I was surprised to learn I did poorly in scientific and technical tests. I was glad to hear I made the right choice with journalism.
Changing your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager at an insurance company. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to look at my career and skills,' says Donna. Some results surprised her. 'I didn't know I had a talent for design. But I had to consider the cost of retraining,' she says. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. 'I decided to use my current skills and move to a job better suited for me. Now, I work as a Public Relations officer. Career Analysts helped me see what I wanted to do. I've recommended them to friends who are also happy with the service.'
Some people feel they wouldn't have made changes without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services led Juliet Greene, 26, to make big decisions. 'After working at a bank for six years, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I didn't know what to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget things you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course this year. The advice was worth the fee. I'm much happier and more positive now.'
However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I didn't know where to go in my career. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary drop or a lot of retraining. I wasn't told anything new about myself,' she says. 'You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt a friend could have given me similar advice.'

**Fun at the Dentist's?**
If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you will see bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain, instead of going for regular check-ups. That's because they are scared." To change this, he has tried to make a place where people are not afraid. That's why he decided not to wear a white coat. He thinks people connect white coats with pain. Jerome believes dental treatment should happen in a relaxed, interesting, and even fun atmosphere.
This is surprising for many people who think dental visits are painful or very formal. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past bad experiences." One of his new ways to help people relax is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental office in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. The headsets are used for the first check-up, where the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I look at their teeth. Then the headset shows a special camera view, giving the patient a tour around their mouth." Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their visit.
Another important thing is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome explains, "When people walk in, I want them to know with all their senses that it's not like going to the dentist's. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make people nervous if they are scared of dentists." I found the gentle smell in the office very nice.
Although he is known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, Jerome wants to say that he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of the treatment is the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, instead of scraping them. It feels a bit strange at first, but as long as people are relaxed, it is not painful at all.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. "One thing I learned there was that when you make it easier for the patient, you make it easier for yourself," he explains. He sees his patient-focused attitude as the start of a slow change towards less formality in the traditional British dentistry profession.
At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks him what video he'd like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment, and it's no surprise. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a regular dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**
Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a big business around the world. At Easter, people in Britain spend over £230 million on chocolate. Eight percent of all chocolate is bought at this time. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate. Although chocolate was made in factories starting in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago.
The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, they become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans. This is a misspelling from the 17th century when they were also called cacoa and cocao beans.
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. The Aztecs flavored the chocolate drink with spices and used it for ceremonies and to welcome visitors. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread to the rest of Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses were opened in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate.
Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. But in 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the crushed beans. The chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847 when a Bristol company, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. A Swiss company then added milk solids, creating milk chocolate.
At the start of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville (ville is French for town) to add some French style. But then Cadbury's famous Dairy Milk bar, first called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular. Clever advertising linked it to the healthy qualities of milk from the English countryside, making it a rival to the more luxurious French brands.
Now, chocolate consumption in Britain is about four bars each week. This has made manufacturers look for new ways to attract customers. The latest idea is the 'extended line', where a chocolate bar becomes an ice cream, a soft drink, or a dessert to tempt those who are tired of regular snacks.
Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices at the end of the 1980s. Since most cacao farmers work on a very small scale, many had to stop farming. Perhaps you could think of them as you enjoy your next chocolate bar.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
Peter Cooke is 83 years old and has become very skilled in his art. He still wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But for now, he is happy to focus on making beautiful and unique objects from shells, a skill he has perfected over the last ten years. 
As he shows me around his apartment, he says, "Tell me if I am boring you." But Peter is not boring at all. He is very enthusiastic and charming, and his work is beautiful. He points to some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace and says, "I won't mind if people don't buy them because I love them. I never planned to sell my work. Some friends visited me five years ago and said, 'You should have an exhibition. People need to see these. We'll talk to a gallery owner.'"
This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The pieces are expensive, with some costing around £2,000, but Peter doesn't mind if his fireplace is empty. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he doesn't set the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else in the world makes work like his. The gallery owner told him, "One day you'll stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won't be any more."
Peter wishes he had started this work earlier in life because he could have made even more wonderful things. Although he still has ideas, he feels more physically limited now. However, his work is far from the usual shell crafts found in seaside shops. He creates boxes covered in tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of realistic flowers.
Peter has his own method and uses materials he finds. He uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just does itself," but his attention to detail and color is impressive.
Peter's search for beautiful, tiny shells has taken him to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who accuse him of harming beaches. He says, "When I collect shells, I hear people crushing them with their feet faster than I can collect them. The sea also breaks them up. I would never collect shells with living creatures in them, but once they are empty, why shouldn't I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially when you see the beauty of his work.

**The Schoolgirl Model**
When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, you will probably find her studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw finds out more.
"I'm afraid Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, fine," I said, "no problem." I was trying to convince myself that all the bad things I had read about models were not true, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming to my mind. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided a visit to the hairdresser's would be more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she would be rushing. She could be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions.
But when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she was with her mother. Kira was not dressed in expensive designer clothes but in a simple black dress and trainers. There was no sign of a selfish attitude; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work, she explained. Apart from looking very young, her mother was a normal mum - clearly proud of her successful daughter.
Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense since it was not planned. It was her older sister who decided that she should enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should go in for it," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When the call came to tell her that she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work.
Kira now finds that one of the hardest things she has to do is manage her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers have become used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, a few unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I have too high an opinion of myself." This kind of remark must be hard for Kira to deal with, since there can't be many people as successful as her who are less self-important. But she says, "They assume that because I've suddenly become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident - not in a bad way, but I'm able to stand up for myself more."
As a busy model, her social life is obviously affected. The Select agency can call at any time and tell her that she is wanted for a job the next day. "If my friends are going out together, I can't say I'll come, because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get broken, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"
Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they even take their school-leaving exams. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do as a career if she didn't have the outstanding beauty that seems certain to take her to the top of the profession. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

'Father and Son Start Gold Rush Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from Canada's cold north to the hot climate of Africa to find valuable metals. The father and son team - one an explorer, the other a mineral expert - think their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they believe they are very close to a five million dollar gold vein. 'As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated,' said Terence, 68, from Liverpool. The pair have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began after the father read about gold worth millions of pounds in the 'Dolgellau gold belt', an area around the Welsh town with the same name. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, father and son chose the best area of land to study. Since they first cleared away the plants and found bits of gold in the rocks, they have spent the past ten years getting permission for their work from the owners, taking samples of the earth, and removing old cars and rubbish. They then started digging out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now they are running out of money. Having spent their savings chasing their dream, they need to find someone to invest £50,000 in the project to dig the mine a few more meters to where the gold is. Chris Madden says, 'At the moment, this looks doubtful although we've got quite a few people we can contact.' As word spread through the valleys last week about the dig, the magic attraction of gold started to interest the locals as well as the gold diggers. Dolgellau relies on tourists, and residents are cautiously hopeful. 'It would encourage more people to come here if they are right,' said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, 'but if these two find gold I hope millions of people are not going to come and dig up the hillside.' The Welsh gold industry has declined a lot since its peak in the late 1880s, when thousands worked in hundreds of mines around the countryside. One of the last remaining mines at Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. Now, however, individual gold-diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. 'Searching for gold is very emotional,' said Hall, 70. 'It's adventurous and exciting, the wonder of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time.' '

**IN HOT WATER**
Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University as a lecturer and researcher in marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. When she is not teaching, she goes on dives to study underwater volcanoes. She uses a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to dive three kilometers down into the ocean. Inside the vehicle, space is very tight, and she can touch the two pilots next to her. They cannot stand or move much and must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency, they can press a panic button to release a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. However, no one has tested it yet, and it might not be a pleasant ride.
Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, are many underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment to study the effects of a program that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. The water flows at one meter per second and is 350 degrees hot. Rachel was only scared once, during a dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she was going to die. But nothing happened, and they were relieved to be safe.
Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in real life was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere under all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't take any more. My mind couldn't handle any more foreign timetables, money, or languages. "Never again," I said, as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could spend a whole month going anywhere I wanted in Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've learned to sleep in the corridor of a train, the rhythm rocking you into a deep sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you have a very simple approach to travel, and encourages incredible wastefulness that can lead to burning socks that have become too smelly, and getting rid of books when finished. On the other hand, this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail, for common sense and reasoning can be thrown out of the window along with the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to achieve this carefree attitude is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that lets young people travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be pretty special. On that first trip, my friends and I didn't know the possibilities of this type of train ticket, thinking it was just a cheap way to get to and from our chosen campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel was too tempting, for there was always just one more country over the border, always that little bit further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was a first holiday without parents, as it was for most other Inter-Railers, and in organizing our own timetable we left out everything except the most immediately available sights. This was the chance to escape the guided tour, an opportunity to do something different. I took great pride in the fact that, in many places, all I could be bothered to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by, and to have a good time doing so. In this, we were no different from most of the other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food and water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. It is as if the city in which you arrive never actually existed until the train pulls in at the station and you are able to see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and seeing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind. Everybody knows what is there, but it is meaningless until you view it yourself. This is what makes other people's holiday photos so boring. While the train trip won't allow you to discover anything new in the world sense, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best opportunity to recognize this ... though in our case it didn't happen immediately.

'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your baggage is missing. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. At worst, you might be in a different climate and have to wear clothes that are not suitable. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it is common for regular travelers to lose their luggage at some point. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and no airline can promise that your checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes. 
Airlines ask passengers to check in early to give enough time for baggage to be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between flights, and these are also longer to allow for baggage transfers. Usually, the system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights and cause the baggage system to fail. Human error or accidents, like a torn destination label, can also cause problems. These issues can be worse at large airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport had over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.
To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when possible and check in early. If you must change planes or want a cheaper flight, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

'The Kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees hang over the stream, shading the shallow water. The main colors are soft greens, mud browns, and the different yellows of sunlight, as gentle as the sounds of water in the breeze. The bird moves quickly through the scene, like a flash of light and motion. It disappears in a second, but the image stays in your mind, its power bigger than its size. Charlie James loved kingfishers from a young age. He cannot explain exactly why he is so drawn to this little bird. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek myth, the kingfisher was a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became the blue of the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. There is some truth in this story. Even though kingfishers look blue, their feathers have no blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers reflects light and makes them look blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich green, depending on the light. It's no surprise that some wildlife photographers love them. The colors and the fact that kingfishers can be watched from a hideout make them a favorite subject. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back in minutes and sat just a meter away. But it took him four years to get his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became very important in his life. He spent as much time as he could by a stream full of kingfishers. But school took away time with the birds, so he missed classes and did not do well in school. However, his interest in the kingfisher, the only one of its family to breed in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He then worked as an assistant to the editor and later became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make the best kingfisher film. 'No speech, just beautiful images that say it all,' he says. 'I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings ...' He stops speaking, thinking of the bird's colors that still excite him. His photos show some of his feelings, but Charlie knows there is more to his relationship with the kingfisher than his work can show.'

**Conducting an Orchestra: Five New Conductors Share Their Stories**
**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, got a big chance when she asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado's practice in Vienna. She ended up replacing an absent assistant and was later asked to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. No, I wasn't nervous. I always felt comfortable in front of an orchestra." Anne, who is from America, works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first opportunity, she has helped Abbado with several projects.
**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of being a conductor is convincing people to give you the right chances. He won a big competition in 1991 after failing in two others. Looking back, he thinks the timing was perfect: "If it had happened earlier, I might have disappeared." The competition gave him many chances to perform and work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he worries about being known only for the competition: "If in three years my name is still linked to it, I'll be concerned." But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which hired him after the competition, are inviting him back. "If this doesn't happen, your career can fall apart."
**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who started Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice time needed for opera. "The music deserves four weeks of attention," says Kani, who began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business area until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Starting lessons with Sian Edwards was a key moment for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always been taught by much bigger people, which makes a big difference." She likes the complexity of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the singers' personalities."
**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
"Conducting was a surprise for me, but it's very interesting," says Roger Vignoles, 48. It's not a strange move for him, though. He started as a musician with an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something new for him. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I tried my best to get the performance I wanted. People respect my musical ability. I'm learning from all my experiences, both in music style and performing. Now, I'll do whatever people ask to find out what I enjoy."
**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed a young assistant conductor, Wayne Marshall, and told his agent about him. Marshall, now 32, soon found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was challenging. He even had to deal with musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was tough with them. I always gave a clear beat and got the best result I could. Many musicians don't seem to need advice from a conductor. But I'm not afraid to say what I want. If people see you're worried, it gets worse. I've never formally studied conducting, and no book tells you how to do it, but people have been kind to me. I am determined and know what I like."

**Theme Parks in Britain**
If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to try some of the best parks.
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**
Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. But we were surprised! The park is great for young children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the kids wanted to stay longer. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and scenery. However, the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is beautiful, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, including adults.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**
After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus with its amazing trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared, they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is fun for younger kids. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small for it. The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are great. On one ride, I couldn't sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**
We arrived at 1 p.m. and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great park for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. We waited 30 minutes for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the children were older, they might find it a bit boring, but they were the right age and loved it.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**
The park says there is 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very scary, according to Ben. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. The staff were mixed; some were great with young children, but not all were friendly. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We couldn't tell the kids we were leaving early!

**Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women's Stories**
**A. Christine Hogan**  
Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly income of over £200,000 and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Before marriage, she worked with computers, so her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. Christine was careful with spending and always informed the bank manager if she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, and local customers usually pick up their work.
**B. Maggy Sasanow**  
Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She says, "I enjoy being independent." Maggy studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but after marrying and moving to the countryside, she couldn't find such work. She started her own business, creating 50 different greeting cards sold to museums. She works in a large room upstairs. A downside of working from home is the constant household tasks, like mowing the lawn. Her business grows through word of mouth, without advertising. People send work from London because she is cheaper than other artists. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, she finds more advantages than disadvantages.
**C. Delia Turner**  
Delia Turner has a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started eight years ago when the business was growing, and her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. She managed six full-time workers but had to let them go due to economic decline, which was hard because jobs are scarce in the area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and hires women who work from their homes. Delia is ready to lower prices when needed and explore new opportunities.
**D. Tessa Strickland**  
Tessa Strickland manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the country. Tessa enjoys working when she wants. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at odd hours. The challenge is having the discipline to stop working. She publishes children's books from different cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt lonely because all her professional experience was in London.
**E. Meg Rivers**  
Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop with a yearly income of £250,000, employing six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, interested in health, making fruit cakes with quality ingredients. Friends and relatives began requesting cakes, and soon she was sending them across the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made, with a baker, assistant, and professional cake decorator. Meg now manages the business side and doesn't bake. Her biggest challenge has been the financial side, as they didn't have much money to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons, Paul and Huw, are talented musicians and composers, and their father, John, makes musical instruments. 
When Paul was ten years old, he needed a cello. His parents, John and Hetty, found that buying one was very expensive. John, who was a schoolteacher in South Wales, decided to try making one himself. He took evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for about three years. After making a few violins and violas, he made his first cello for Paul. It was so good that Paul used it until recently. John now makes violins full-time and even sold one to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.
Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano and then became interested in the cello. He was inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Huw, on the other hand, chose to play the piano and compose music. He admired Paul's success and wanted to achieve his own.
Paul, now 28, won a major music competition with his father's cello and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at age 20. He recently started using a very old and valuable cello, a Francesco Rugeri, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul will soon perform on television with this cello, but he won't be able to watch it because he has a concert the same night. Huw, now 22, will also be busy, as his String Quartet will be performed in London for the first time.
John and Hetty are proud of their sons and try to keep up with their busy musical careers.

'Looking after the countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is an organization that works to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. Gareth says a warden needs common sense and must be good with people because they work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people wanted the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. Gareth got the job because of his local knowledge and farming experience, even though he didn't have formal training. He still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. His farming background also helps him with the physical work like building fences, planting trees, and making walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and realizes now that farming has changed the countryside. He says it's not the farmers' fault because they followed government advice. When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists disagreed, but now they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's work includes conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. He makes sure jobs are done well and cheaply. He enjoys seeing projects finished, although he spends a lot of time on paperwork. Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He likes talking to the public, but some people annoy him when they act like they own the place. If you have common sense and like outdoor work, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But don't expect a job on the Lleyn Peninsula to open up soon!'

**The Netball Captain**
In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a typical day before next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in the supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."
"My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships," says Kendra. "I'm on a strict schedule to be as fit as possible." These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries taking part. "We'll have home support, which is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will expect us to start with a good game."
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they'll be exciting to play. They have lots of skill." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself to play each day, there's no rest between games. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance."
In the fifteen years since she started playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. "You don't train so hard not to win," says Kendra. "But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We're all friendlier after the game."
Netball is also more scientific about fitness testing. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. I support and encourage the team."
"From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned," she says. "I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**
How can parents help a child with great musical talent? It is not always easy to know the best way to support their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and behaves badly. Most schools can help children who are good at academic subjects, but musically talented children need special support that regular schools might not offer, especially if music is not a main focus there. These children, and those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.
There are five specialist music schools in Britain. These schools are quite new and aim to create a supportive environment for talented children aged seven to eighteen. Here, they can develop their skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend one third to half of their day on music activities, like individual lessons, playing in orchestras, singing, conducting, and learning music theory. They also practice for several hours a day in special rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program, focusing on important subjects like English, maths, basic sciences, and languages. Students can also study more subjects if they want.
All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and many teachers. Most students live at the school full-time, which means they spend their important growing years with others who have similar interests.
What are the downsides? One big issue is the cost; fees are high (PS12,000-PS17,000 a year for boarders). However, schools try to help parents of very talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Also, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. School directors often question if it is wise to admit children as young as seven into such a strict environment. They do say their main goal is to help children become well-rounded individuals.
There is a risk that separating musically talented children early can cause stress. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to a feeling of failure. But specialist schools watch each student's progress closely and offer help if needed. Many former students feel they gained a lot from the excellent music teaching, but some worry about the limited academic program, which is less important than music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very smart and can handle academic challenges, so they might feel unhappy if their academic needs are not met.
For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide if they want a specialist education. Children who are also good at academics might do well in a less specialized school, like one with a strong music department, or by combining regular school with music training at a junior music college. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with great teachers and group music experiences. However, this option might not work for families who live far from big cities like London.

**An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread seeds everywhere. The garden has a nice mix of colors, shapes, and structures, thanks to the previous owners who loved gardening. They left plants that Susan liked, and she also got their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny didn't agree with some of Susan's ideas, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood.
Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She says, "I don't set the whole thing up at once." She paints one flower at a time, which can take a few days, and then adds more flowers. Sometimes, it takes a couple of years to finish a painting.
Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. She also enjoys watching the flowers change as they age. For example, tulips change shape and open up when left in water. At first, they seem boring, but they twist and turn over time.
Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers back then because they looked fake to her. She was fascinated by wildflowers growing in difficult places like rocks or cliffs.
Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they fit well in her garden. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two exhibitions coming up and many flowers to paint, she finds it hard to work in the garden. She now has an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year doing this job. People call her by her nickname, Pilch. She works for a company that provides cooking and cleaning services for visitors who come to ski and stay in chalets, which are wooden houses typical of the area.
Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University and graduated last summer. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to meet successful people," she says.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. "They get everything - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After the guests finish breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she says is "the worst part of the job." By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She tries to ski as much as possible. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m."
Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting, but she does not nap. "It's a bad idea if you do," she says. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. Sarah cleans up after dinner and loads the dishwasher. "There's nothing worse than a messy kitchen in the morning." Sometimes she chats with the guests, other times they prefer to be left alone. "Good guests can make a week great, but some weeks don't go as well."
Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start at Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and maybe end at Dick's T-Bar," she says. But she never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. "A tough day," she says, "when you don't want to be tired while cooking breakfast."
On Sunday, work starts earlier because breakfast must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clean everything - clear breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready." If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests. "They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. I think it's the mountain air."
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need boots or skis by taking them to the ski shop and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it's time for dinner again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early," she says.

'Changing lives with a Stranger Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day in the offices of the magazine Marie Claire. 'Choosing what to wear for my day at Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at work. First, I went to a photo studio, then to see new fashion items, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm, peaceful place - and here I was rushing around when I could be sitting quietly with an animal. Some of the fashion team seemed quite stressed - my job doesn't really get stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, it made me laugh to think that I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested to see how magazines work, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo so I'll stay there.' Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent the day at London Zoo. 'I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in - which was good, as I got very dirty. As I touched one of the elephants, I thought Mandie would probably be packing up clothes in the cupboard. By five o'clock, I smelled bad but I'd had such a great day. When I stop working in fashion, I could see myself working with elephants - but maybe in Africa.' Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, went on location with the television gardening programme Ground Force. 'I was very excited about meeting the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the programme presenter, was really nice. One of the things I liked was the chance to be outside. Depending on my shifts, I sometimes never see daylight. Even though it was hard work, it was great fun. I thought I was pretty strong but I felt weak compared with the rest of the team. My idea of landscape gardening had not included hard work or careful planning. I was more an enthusiastic than effective gardener, so I don't plan to leave my other job.' Charlie Dimmock, landscape gardener with the TV programme Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. 'I made beds and gave out tablets. I expected to faint when I was doing some jobs, but I was surprised to find that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared with my normal male environment. I feel my job is a real waste of time compared with nursing. My day at the hospital was not exactly pleasant but it left me with a great sense of satisfaction.' Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with the airline Ryanair as a member of the cabin crew. 'I changed into the uniform, and the moment I put it on I felt completely different - people suddenly look up to you. Before the flight, our supervisor told us about safety, what to do if someone had a heart attack - which I knew about from my fitness training. When the passengers boarded the flight to Paris I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me and I felt very self-conscious. On the return journey, we had 80 schoolchildren on board who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to look after.' Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with the airline Ryanair, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. 'I was worried about doing this swap as I don't do any exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, you meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was very surprised at lunch to see that some of the trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be a bit healthier.''

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**
**A. Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to go back often. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast that crosses into Italy. It takes you past amazing sea views. No matter the weather or time of year, it is always beautiful. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. You feel like you are looking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively because there is a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.
**B. Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which goes across the desert in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.
**C. Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I've worn it ever since. What I remember about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding.
**D. Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There wasn't a road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliable - we were just given a day. We heard the driver would wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When it appeared, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriages - people even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It was like a dream, like traveling across the moon.
**E. Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite train memories as children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important to me. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming was on an old, unused line maintained by volunteers. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train, and when I went back last year, it was like time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

'Want to get published? If you are thinking about where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has the advice you need. Readers of this magazine often ask, 'I have written this story/book. Can you tell me who to send it to?' The first thing they need to know is that they should research their markets and learn about publishers while improving their writing skills. Turning words into something you can sell requires a lot of knowledge about the 'writing game'. Whatever kind of writing you do, you need to know about the markets you are aiming for. There are several ways to do this, but the best one is by reading everything relevant you can find. Use your local library and visit local bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are accepting at any given time. This knowledge must be updated as new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. New titles come and go all the time. Publishers are always looking for new writers; as writers, we have to make sure we give them what they want. At first, you may not be sure what you want to write. Let's say you want to write short love stories. The first thing you must do is find out which magazines use love stories, a rather limited market these days, and get as many recent copies as you can. Then, learn about the kind of stories they are buying, paying attention to who the readers are. These readers expect different things from their magazine, and the editor is only interested in meeting their needs. Writers often send me their stories saying, 'This has been rejected three times - please tell me if I am wasting my time ... do I stand a chance at all?' As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone. But it is unlikely that the work is ready to be published; so I try to give an honest opinion, but always with a positive viewpoint. The problem is that most new writers are too eager to send their work out, usually long before they are ready to enter the market. If you have only written one story or one article, it is not likely to be published. That almost never happens. When you read about 'success', you usually find that the person has been in the publishing trade or journalism for some years before their current success. When you finally send off some of your work for the first time, immediately start on more work while you wait for a reply; write ten more stories, twenty even. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to think of yourself as a writer, and both your fluency and your confidence will grow. Don't throw any of them away—improve them instead. Also, I advise not showing your work to anyone else, especially in the early stages. Remember that every successful writer has had many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your career as a writer. See if there's a creative writing course near you. If not, try joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from mixing with other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing—every day if possible.'

'No Title On the last day of a bad year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The station didn't feel as airy and clean as usual. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to strangers one by one. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He asked a woman sitting alone a question, then approached a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I might like to talk to her. The man asked, 'Are you travelling to Philadelphia?' 'Well, northbound, yes,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. 'Ma'am,' I heard him ask an old lady, 'are you travelling to Philadelphia?' When she said, 'Wilmington,' he didn't say anything, just moved on to a couple with matching luggage. I stood up from my pillar and moved closer, pretending to look at the train platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn't. I probably seemed unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then moved to the bench at the other end. He looked stressed. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She lowered her book. She was around thirty-five, older than me. A school-teacher type. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Yes, I am.' 'Could I ask you a favour?' I stopped a few feet away and looked at my left wrist. (I don't own a watch.) Even without looking, I could tell she was cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, 'Nothing too difficult, I promise!' They announced my train. People started moving toward Gate E, the older couples pulling their wheeled bags like big pets. I heard the man talking. 'My daughter's flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; she didn't know what to do.' The woman clucked sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet, waiting to see where he was going with this. 'I told her to stay there. I would find someone here to take her passport.' A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was so urgent? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a poor excuse, in my opinion. Also, it was too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have been logical, but a padded envelope the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel the contents! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut. Watch yourself, lady, I thought silently.'

**Gary and Me**
John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. 
I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for what I wanted. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory, and I was upset because I was left alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife took care of the children and did all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This was good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life.
Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. When he was older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with small jobs, and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined. He used to wake up even before me in the morning. In a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He would make over a hundred meals, and I knew he would go into catering because he had talent. So when he told me, 'Dad, I need to do work experience for school,' I sent him to a friend who has a restaurant.
Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary is: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can do well. He understood when I said, 'Gary, if you want to achieve something in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it's too late.' Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students, who are usually beginners, were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He had prepared everything. That's my son! In the end, he was helping other people.
None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. I'm very proud of him. I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it because no one gives you anything. He saw the opportunity he was given and took it with both hands. You talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even ten percent of what you tell them, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.

Finding a good flat in Dublin at an affordable price was very difficult. The best way was through personal contacts: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a place, that often worked. But if, like Jo, you had just arrived in Dublin, you had no personal contacts, no one to tell you about a vacant bedsit. So, you had to stay in a hostel and search. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going. Everyone at her school assumed she would leave. Who would stay in a small, boring town? That's all she heard for years. Everyone wanted to leave, see life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family would help them settle. But no one from Jo's year was going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so she would be safe. Her father hoped they kept it warm; hostels were known for being cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay a whole week in a hostel. But Jo didn't know they were still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. Please let it be nice, let them like me, let it not be too expensive! There wasn't a queue because it was more 'Third Girl Wanted' than 'Flat to Let'. The 'own television' part made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement. The flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who was obviously not chosen, was coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.' 'Oh,' said Jo and continued climbing. 'Hello,' said the girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, and said, "Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Pauline was a punk, Jo noted with surprise. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one. 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called.' Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one said 'Nessa', one said 'Pauline', and the other said 'Other'. 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' she said kindly.

'Behind the dolphin's smile People love dolphins. We like to see them in seaside marinas, films, and TV shows. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about the decline of dolphins. Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, understand human feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the wild seas. TV has made us love them more. First, there was Flipper, and now there's Darwin from Seaquest. However, these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think such popular animals are protected by law and live in special marine areas. But this is not true, and not having plans to protect them could become a big wildlife problem. There are forty different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are the striped, the common, the bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two usually live far out in the sea. They are seen only in small groups, quickly passing ships, and we know little about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in river mouths in Britain, like the Thames. Now, they are only found in the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show skin injuries, indicating stress. Dolphins' complex habits make it hard to know why their numbers are falling. Overfishing, which is reducing the world's fish stocks and threatening local fishing industries, also threatens porpoises and dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are removed by fishing, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use huge nets that float or are pulled quickly through the sea. Recently, hundreds of dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks, ropes, and cuts on their bodies show they died because they were caught in these nets. Waste and other substances in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can digest them, and they build up in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk rich in pesticides, passing the poison to their young.
